text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Assassination in Haiti: What We Know, and Don’t Know
text: During a nighttime attack on July 7, a group of assassins fatally shot President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti and wounded his wife, Martine Moïse, in their private residence on the outskirts of the capital, Port-au-Prince. The assassination rocked the nation, stoking fear and confusion among residents and the Haitian diaspora about what is to come.

headline: North Dakota sues the Biden administration over oil and gas leases.
text: The State of North Dakota has sued the Biden administration for suspending new oil and gas leases on federal lands and waters, claiming it will cost the state almost $5 billion in lost revenue and keep more than half a billion barrels of oil in the ground.

headline: James Kallstrom Dies at 78; Led F.B.I. Review of T.W.A. Crash
text: James K. Kallstrom, the New York F.B.I. chief who painstakingly spent 16 months investigating why T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded 12 minutes after takeoff and crashed into the Atlantic Ocean in 1996, killing all 230 people onboard, died on Sunday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 78.

headline: Is the Rise of the Substack Economy Bad for Democracy?
text: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: California Braces for Dangerous Weekend of Record-Setting Heat
text: California is bracing for another dangerous heat wave and record-breaking temperatures this weekend, just two weeks after a heat dome descended on the normally temperate Pacific Northwest, killing hundreds of people and capping North America’s hottest June on record.

headline: Feeding Thousands After the Building Collapse
text: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Ten days before the coronavirus pandemic shuttered Florida restaurants last year, Shemi Bar-Natan had just begun a new venture after spending a decade in the Israeli army, opening a hummus bar less than a mile from the apartment building that collapsed last month.

headline: A Crucial Test Is Coming for Biden’s Climate Agenda
text: Climate change is everywhere you look: in the staggering heat wave that hit the Pacific Northwest last week, killing more than 150 people; in the Western wildfire season that started early this year and is likely to be severe; in the weather throughout June, which was the hottest on record in North America; and even at summer camps where children are having “flashlight campfires” instead of the real thing.

headline: Man Charged With Hate Crimes in Stabbing of Rabbi in Boston
text: A man who stabbed a rabbi outside a Jewish school in Boston this month was charged on Thursday with hate crimes after investigators discovered that he had expressed anti-Semitic views, prosecutors said.

headline: The Trumpian Roots of the Chip Crisis
text: What’s the current state of the U.S. economy? A quick summary might be “booming with bottlenecks.”

headline: How Crowded Are America’s National Parks? See for Yourself.
text: Largely freed from domestic travel restrictions, Americans have been flocking to national parks in record numbers this spring and summer. Several parks — including Yellowstone National Park and Grand Teton National Park — have already set monthly visitation records. Many sites are gearing up for their busiest years in history.

headline: Political Crisis in Haiti Deepens Over Rival Claims to Power
text: The political storm in Haiti intensified on Thursday as two competing prime ministers claimed the right to run the country, setting up an extraordinary power struggle over who had the legal authority to govern after the brazen assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in his home the day before.

headline: Meet this year’s finalists.
text: More than half have experience on the national stage. One eighth grader is a seasoned veteran of the most competitive circuit. A third call Texas home.

headline: White House offers assistance after Haiti’s president is assassinated.
text: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, on Thursday offered U.S. assistance to Haiti in the wake of the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse and renewed American support for legislative and presidential elections that had been scheduled for September.

headline: Alleged Assassins in Haiti Claimed to Be D.E.A.
text: In videos filmed from nearby buildings and synchronized by the The New York Times, the group of commandos who appeared to be arriving to assassinate President Jovenel Moïse shouted that they were part of a U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency operation.

headline: Entire Families Were Lost in the Surfside Collapse. Here Is One of Their Stories.
text: MIAMI — Just after dawn on that morning that now feels like forever ago, Annette Guara Hurst hurried to her computer. A high-rise condo building had collapsed in a Surfside, Fla., neighborhood familiar to her, and she needed to see the file where she keeps her family’s addresses. She scanned the list, looking for her youngest brother, praying that her gut was wrong.

headline: Biden Legal Team Divided on Scope of Rights of Guantánamo Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration legal team is divided over whether the government should say that detainees at the American naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have due process rights under the Constitution, according to people familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: In Forceful Defense of Afghan Withdrawal, Biden Says U.S. Achieved Its Objectives
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden vigorously defended his decision to end America’s 20-year war in Afghanistan on Thursday, asserting that the United States can no longer afford the human cost or strategic distraction of a conflict that he said had strayed far from its initial mission.

headline: Man Arrested in Killing of Georgia Golf Pro and Two Others
text: The authorities in Georgia said on Thursday that they had arrested a man who had fatally shot three men — a golf pro and two men whose bodies were found in the back of a pickup truck at a suburban Atlanta country club on Saturday.

headline: White House Sets Ethics Plan for Sales of Hunter Biden’s Art
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has helped develop a system for Hunter Biden to sell pieces of his art without him, or anyone in the administration, knowing who bought them, the latest effort to respond to criticism over how President Biden’s son makes his money.

headline: White House, Facing Voting Rights Defeats, Expands Investment
text: WASHINGTON — Facing an onslaught of state-level ballot restrictions and gridlock in Congress over voting rights legislation, the White House detailed a multimillion-dollar plan on Thursday to register voters and fight voter suppression.

headline: Who reads the spelling bee words?
text: Judging by his résumé, Jacques A. Bailly is eminently qualified to serve as the official pronouncer of the Scripps National Spelling Bee, a job he has held since 2003.

headline: The Nation Needs a Reality-Based G.O.P. Only the Kook Caucus Is Stepping Up.
text: Brace yourself, America. Next year’s midterms have the potential to stock the Republican Party at all levels with rabble-rousers that make the Gingrich revolutionaries of 1994 and the Tea Partiers of 2010 look like RINO squishes.

headline: Mexico to Allow Union Vote at G.M. Plant After U.S. Complaint
text: The United States on Thursday reached a deal with Mexico to give workers at a General Motors plant in the country the ability to vote on a collective bargaining agreement in “free and democratic conditions.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Restaurants Mobilizing to Feed Thousands After Building Collapse
text: “When the circus leaves town, we’re here.”

headline: Corrections: July 9, 2021
text: An article on Thursday about an attack in Afghanistan by the Taliban misstated the day on which the Taliban broke into a jail in Badghis Province. It was Wednesday, as noted elsewhere in the article, not Tuesday.

headline: Citing the Delta Variant, Pfizer Will Pursue Booster Shots and a New Vaccine
text: Pfizer and BioNTech announced on Thursday that they were developing a version of the coronavirus vaccine that targets Delta, a highly contagious variant that has spread to nearly 100 countries. The companies expect to begin clinical trials of the vaccine in August.

headline: Home of the Polka Hall of Fame
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Just look at this puzzle by Robyn Weintraub. It’s gorgeous, and I don’t attribute attractiveness to crossword puzzles on the regular.

headline: Heavy Rains Pound New York City, Flooding Subway Stations and Roads
text: Heavy rains continued to spill through New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on Friday morning as Tropical Storm Elsa made its way up the Northeast coast.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Though Americans have been able to travel to the E.U. since June, residents of Europe’s Schengen area, Ireland and the U.K. have been essentially barred from traveling to the U.S. since March 2020. The C.D.C. has also halted travel from some non-European countries: China, Iran, Brazil, South Africa and India.

headline: He Couldn’t Remember That We Broke Up
text: I used to receive messages like this from my ex-boyfriend: “Did we have a joke about flamingos?” And: “How did I get the scar on my hand?”

headline: My Country Did Everything Right on Covid. And the Worst Is Still Here.
text: Early in the pandemic, Uganda bought itself precious time at great economic cost to protect its people from Covid-19.

headline: A Couture Horror Story at Maison Margiela
text: PARIS — Well, that was a plot twist no one could have foreseen. The very last show of the newly back-in-person couture week — the show that would have been (will be, when it happens) a historic show, because it would have been the first official couture show from a Black American designer — the Pyer Moss show, scheduled on Thursday in Irvington, N.Y. and livestreamed to Paris, ended up, after three hours of bated-breath waiting, being postponed. Because of rain.

headline: Fallout From Hack of City Law Department Could Linger for Months
text: Among the thousands of lawsuits New York City faces each year, this case was unexceptional — a man suing the city and several police officers over his arrest during a 2016 demonstration. But last week, the case hit a snag for an unusual reason: The city’s Law Department had been hacked, and lawyers were struggling to gain access to important documents.

headline: Chasing After Mysteries in Victoria’s High Country
text: I’ve spent most of the past week talking to people about ghost stories and real-life mysteries in a place where the boundaries between the two often seem hazy: the Victorian high country.

headline: Two rivals aim to take control in Haiti as the president’s death leaves a power vacuum.
text: The political storm in Haiti intensified on Thursday as two competing prime ministers claimed the right to run the country, setting up an extraordinary power struggle over who has the legal authority to govern after the brazen assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in his home the day before.

headline: Two arrested Americans claim they were just ‘translators’ in the assassination plot, a Haitian judge says.
text: Two Americans arrested in connection with the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti this week said that they were not in the room when he was killed and that they had worked only as translators for the hit squad, a Haitian judge said on Friday.

headline: Typing Classes, the Aubrey-Maturin Series and Other Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor:

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, July 9, 2021
text: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Love and Theft’ and ‘The Sirens of Mars’
text: THE ROAD FROM RAQQA: A Story of Brotherhood, Borders, and Belonging, by Jordan Ritter Conn. (Ballantine, 272 pp., $18.) In this riveting account of two grown brothers’ very different journeys out of Syria, Conn “pushes beyond simply humanizing,” Jessica Goudeau wrote in her review. He portrays the United States, where the elder ends up, as also capable of oppression, and finds the two countries’ histories to be “as interconnected as the brothers’ own.”

headline: The ‘Ugly Truth’ About Facebook
text: AN UGLY TRUTHInside Facebook’s Battle for DominationBy Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang

headline: Free Doughnuts Aren’t Going to Boost Vaccination Rates
text: If you were really scared of something — a fear founded on rumor and history, that you could get sick and possibly die, lose your ability to have children, alter your DNA or be left at the mercy of pernicious government surveillance — would you do it anyway, for the prospect of a membership to the Public Theater? Or a free glazed doughnut at Krispy Kreme?

headline: A Happy Union for a Couple Who Skipped Their First Date
text: John Zey was 50 years old when he asked Avis Ranney permission to date her 46-year-old daughter, Kris Ranney, in September 2018. Though the question was a formality, he wasn’t sure the answer would be yes.

headline: The One-Night Stand That Went on Forever
text: It was supposed to be just a one-night stand. Instead, Karina Lopez, 33, and Curtis Rogers, 35, have been together for 12 years and even own three businesses together now, all based in Manhattan and Buffalo, N.Y. — KC Public Relations; KC You There, a wedding planning and design company; and Minibar Mobile.

headline: Critical Race Theory, Comic Books and the Power of Public Schools
text: Eve Ewing’s work as a sociologist, poet, visual artist, podcaster and comic book writer manages to do two things that are often in tension: it gives us a clear picture of how race, power and education work in America right now, and envisions a world that could work radically differently.

headline: A Perfect Moment For a Private Proposal (With a Drone)
text: Dr. Olivia Janssen was clear that she did not want a public proposal. So when Andrew Perra got down on one knee, he knew he had to get creative.

headline: From Fast Friends to Suddenly in Love
text: While surveying a pizza slice with sweet Italian sausage, Blake Song sensed tension. It was a steamy, Southern Californian evening in the summer of 2016, one of many enjoyed in the long friendship of Mr. Song and Bailey Kinsolving. Somehow, though, that night felt different. In the line of the Orange Plaza Pizza Press in Orange, Calif., Mr. Song posed a question to Ms. Kinsolving: “You like me, right?”

headline: Helping Runners With Long Covid Get Back on Their Feet
text: At 17 years old, Nia Raquelle Smith enlisted in the Navy, and subsequently hurt her legs in a training accident, sustaining injuries that left her with nerve damage and on crutches for nine months. She was told that she’d never run again, and, determined to prove her doctors wrong, proceeded to run three marathons.

headline: The Right Answer to a Different Question
text: Kalyn Saulsberry’s profile on the dating app Coffee Meets Bagel said that she liked 1990s things, which Vincent Fong saw as a perfect opportunity for connection.

headline: Cancer Took Away My Ability to Eat, but Not My Love of Food
text: When I moved to New York City in the late 1990s, I discovered ramen. Not the packets at the grocery store in packs of six for $1.00 that I cooked in my dorm room but the hand-pulled noodles served in ramen houses whose steam-fogged windows welcomed you to a hazy world where men in business suits and women in practical shoes sat at tables and bars with their heads facing down over a bowl of broth. Rooms both sweaty and silent, except for the nonstop slurping of noodles. No one even paused for breath.

headline: California Wakes Up From Its Dream
text: LOS ANGELES — California has long been a land of firsts, and this year is no exception.

headline: Their Route to a Future Was Clear
text: Jason Bolicki and Adam Schloff each realized that they were in love just a few months after they initially met, which was in July 2015. By New Year’s Eve of that year, both had concluded that they should get married.

headline: A Fitness App Moonlights as a Men’s Support Group
text: Like other single guys his age, Mack Knight, 40, a software company executive in Los Angeles, has a crew of buddies who like to explore the city, travel and workout together.

headline: The Christian Right Is in Decline, and It’s Taking America With It
text: The presidency of George W. Bush may have been the high point of the modern Christian right’s influence in America. White evangelicals were the largest religious faction in the country. “They had a president who claimed to be one of their own, he had a testimony, talked in evangelical terms,” said Robert P. Jones, chief executive of the Public Religion Research Institute and author of the 2016 book “The End of White Christian America.”

headline: Zaila Avant-garde Makes Spelling History, and Other Moments From the Bee
text: The last word, after hundreds of competitors fell to some of the dictionary’s most colorful monsters, was “Murraya.”

headline: The Family That Buys Together Stays Together
text: Before the pandemic, the Crafts family was scattered: three generations, in three houses, in three different states, with close to zero chance of living together.

headline: A Love That Bloomed in the Lab
text: In 2011, Dr. Edward Ryan Horton spent about a month of his summer break working in the reproductive endocrine unit at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was approaching his final year as an undergraduate at Brown, and focused on securing a full-time job at the lab when he graduated.

headline: Why Record-Breaking Overnight Temperatures Are So Concerning
text: Last month was the hottest June on record in North America, with more than 1,200 daily temperature records broken in the final week alone. But overlooked in much of the coverage were an even greater number of daily records set by a different — and potentially more dangerous — measure of extreme heat: overnight temperatures.

headline: 13 Questions That Led to ‘Will You Marry Me?’
text: Vicky Guo and Patrick Roath were not playing games. From an animated first-date debate on charter schools after the 2016 presidential election, to discussing long distance after three months of dating, the couple were clear about their intentions from the start.

headline: How Should We Do Drugs Now?
text: After a half century spent waging war on drugs, Americans seem ready to sue for peace. The 2020 elections brought plenty of proof that voters have leapt ahead of politicians in recognizing both the failures of the drug war and the potential of certain illicit drugs as powerful tools for healing.

headline: Biden Urges More Scrutiny of Big Businesses, Such as Tech Giants
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed a sweeping executive order on Friday intended to increase competition within the nation’s economy and to limit corporate dominance, factors the White House says have led to higher prices and fewer choices for consumers while dampening pay and restricting the freedom to change jobs.

headline: Banning Abortion Doesn’t Protect Women’s Health
text: During its coming term, the Supreme Court will review the constitutionality of a Mississippi anti-abortion law that criminalizes abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy. Already in Mississippi, only one abortion clinic remains to serve the entire state. This new law, one of the most restrictive anti-abortion measures yet, provides no exemptions in cases of rape or incest. Many see it as the gravest threat to Roe v. Wade ever taken up by the Supreme Court. They are not wrong.

headline: Love Was the Main Attraction on Their Sightseeing Adventure
text: On the day Kevin James LaBuz married Molly Elizabeth Corbett, the groom’s mother made a toast that flowed like a river — the Susquehanna River, to be exact.

headline: A Landlord Says Her Tenants Are Terrorizing Her. She Can’t Evict Them.
text: For more than a year, Vanie Mangal, a physician assistant at a Connecticut hospital, called relatives to tell them that their loved ones were dying of Covid-19, watched as patients gasped their final breaths and feared that she herself would get sick.

headline: Finance Ministers Meet in Venice to Finalize Global Tax Agreement
text: VENICE — The world’s top economic leaders convened on Friday to hash out crucial details of what would be the largest overhaul of the international tax system in a century, kicking off a three-month race to finish a deal by the end of the year.

headline: Citizens, Not the State, Will Enforce New Abortion Law in Texas
text: People across the country may soon be able to sue abortion clinics, doctors and anyone helping a woman get an abortion in Texas, under a new state law that contains a legal innovation with broad implications for the American court system.

headline: Summer in the Cities: Chicago
text: As the pandemic ebbs in the United States, many travelers have been favoring outdoor, away-from-it-all getaways. According to the travel planning site TripIt, over Memorial Day weekend, major cities like Washington, D.C., and New York were trending down, while outdoorsy spots like Palm Springs, Calif., were newly popular. “Two-thirds of my clients are booking houses, ranch stays and hotels in smaller coastal communities,” said Shawna Owen, the owner of Huffman Travel, part of the Virtuoso Network.

headline: How Ronan Farrow Spends His Sundays
text: Ronan Farrow, the investigative journalist who most recently took a deep dive into the Britney Spears conservatorship case for The New Yorker with Jia Tolentino, is usually not described as laid-back. But these days he certainly looks it. “I think the phrase you’re searching for is ’90s boy band,” Mr. Farrow said about growing out his hair, which is usually groomed to a State Department-ready length. “Wasn’t the intention, but seems to be the result.”

headline: The Schlock-Horror Drive-In That Rose From the Grave
text: It was about 2 a.m. on a Sunday when the gross-out horror-comedy “Class of Nuke ’Em High” started playing at the Mahoning Drive-In. This was the last screening at TromaDance, an annual showcase of low-budget horror and sex comedies produced by the Queens-based Troma movie studio. Earlier that evening, about 600 cars had piled into the drive-in in Lehighton, Pa., but by 2 a.m., only the die-hards remained. Kevin Schmidt, an extra in the film, was among them.

headline: Patricia Marroquin Norby Is Bringing a Native Perspective to the Met
text: Big, bold and by many accounts about time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s 56-word land-acknowledgment plaque, placed on its Fifth Avenue facade in May, honors the Indigenous peoples past and present (principally the Lenape) whose homeland the institution occupies.

headline: Regina King and Bradley Cooper Party for the Moth
text: In-person galas are back. While some benefit parties remain virtual, charities and cultural groups are finding that there is no substitute for the real thing. On June 22, the Moth, a nonprofit devoted to storytelling, held a starry gala at Spring Studios in TriBeCa. The Hollywood-heavy crowd included Regina King and Kemp Powers, who were honored, as well as Bradley Cooper, Keith Lucas and Kenny Lucas. One night later, the Bronx Museum of the Arts marked its 50th year with a party and exhibition by the Harlem-based artist Wardell Milan.

headline: Accidental Artists Declare Their Love, One Rubik’s Cube at a Time
text: Phil Pollack didn’t pretend he knew a lot about art when he took Jenn Loeb on a date to the Whitney Museum in 2017. She wasn’t much into art, either. Both remember feeling slightly mystified as they poked through galleries under the museum’s gridded ceilings.

headline: Architect Finds a Sense of Belonging for His Family’s Homeland, and for Himself
text: The first time Omar Degan set foot in Mogadishu, in October 2017, he quickly grasped that it bore little resemblance to the picturesque cityscape his parents, Somali refugees who had fled to Europe, described to him growing up.

headline: It’s Hollywood Barbie’s Moment (and She’s Bringing Her Friends)
text: For 62 years, Barbie has been the hardest-working woman in the toy aisle, using a dizzying array of outfits and accessories — and, lately, changing body shapes and skin tones — while gliding from one career to the next. Astrophysicist Barbie. Ballerina Barbie. Chicken Farmer Barbie. Firefighter Barbie.

headline: All the Recipes Our Food Staff Cooked in June
text: Isn’t summer grocery shopping just pure ecstasy? The possibilities are endless: succulent stone fruit and berries as far as the eye can see, all the fresh seafood you could ever want, and vegetables — summer squash, okra, corn — that taste as if they were plucked from the sun-warmed dirt just hours earlier. Last month, the Food staff made the most of summer’s bounty while keeping the recipes short, sweet and, most importantly, low on heat (with a few exceptions). Here are the best recipes we cooked in June.

headline: Did a Cuttlefish Write This?
text: Captive cuttlefish require entertainment when they eat. Dinner and a show — if they can’t get live prey, then they need some dancing from a dead shrimp on a stick in their tank.

headline: What we know and don’t know about the assassination.
text: During an attack in the early hours of Wednesday, a group of assassins fatally shot President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti and wounded his wife, Martine Moïse, in their private residence on the outskirts of the capital, Port-au-Prince.

headline: Pfizer says it will pursue booster shots and a new vaccine, citing the Delta variant.
text: Pfizer and BioNTech announced on Thursday that they were developing a version of the coronavirus vaccine that targets Delta, a highly contagious variant that has spread to nearly 100 countries. The companies expect to begin clinical trials of the vaccine in August.

headline: Queens Hustles Back to Life and Hawaii’s Proud Surfers: The Week in Narrated Articles
text: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: The Assassination of Haiti’s President
text: Sometime after 1 a.m. on Wednesday, a group of 50 men stormed the Haitian presidential compound.

headline: Biden’s New Push
text: The U.S. economy has been less dynamic in the 21st century, by many measures, than it was in the late 20th century.

headline: Political instability was fueling a rise in gang violence even before the president was killed.
text: The assassination of President Jovenel Moïse on Wednesday by gunmen who broke into his private residence was a stark reminder of the violence that has plagued Haiti for years and escalated in recent weeks.

headline: I.M.F. Board Backs $650 Billion Aid Plan to Help Poor Countries
text: VENICE — The International Monetary Fund took a step on Friday toward easing widening global inequality and helping poor nations get access to vaccines, saying its executive board approved a plan to issue $650 billion worth of reserve funds that countries can use to buy vaccines, finance health care and pay down debt.

headline: Investors Seek to Cut ‘Pharma Bro’ Out of His Company
text: For years, Kevin Mulleady was an ally of Martin Shkreli. He worked for one of the pharmaceutical executive’s hedge funds and later served as an executive at the company where Mr. Shkreli infamously raised a lifesaving drug’s price 5,000 percent.

headline: ‘Last Summer’ Review: Growing Pains
text: The film “Last Summer” plays like an extended montage advertising the arresting views and clear Mediterranean waters of southern Turkey. Like a migratory fish, the teenage Deniz (Fatih Sahin) is lucky to spend summers on this divine coastline beaching, discoing and bronzing in the seaside town where his family has a cottage. This gauzy coming-of-age movie (on Netflix) is set during the summer of 1997, as Deniz tags along with his cool older sister, Ebru (Aslihan Malbora), while nursing puppy love for her teasing bestie, Asli (Ece Cesmioglu).

headline: After 45 Years, a Cop Still Looks After His Favorite (Base) Thief
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Catch up: A top student loan servicer won’t renew its contract.
Britain’s economy grew for the fourth straight month, but more slowly than expected.
text: The British economy grew 0.8 percent in May as more pandemic restrictions were lifted, official data showed, but the pace of growth has slowed and economists warn that returning to prepandemic levels will be harder, especially if consumers react cautiously to rising coronavirus infections.

headline: M.L.B. Draft: Marcelo Mayer and Five Other Players to Watch
text: The 2021 Major League Baseball player draft will begin on Sunday in Colorado, the site of this year’s All-Star Game, and will continue for 20 rounds over three days.

headline: Tencent Games uses facial recognition to restrict children’s screen time.
text: The Chinese internet conglomerate Tencent said this week that it would deploy facial recognition technology in its video games in an attempt to close a loophole in restrictions aimed at limiting screen time.

headline: Hosting an Airbnb Right Now Is Harder Than You Think
text: Last August, Ben and Elana Vorspan bought a cabin in Big Bear City, Calif., a two-hour drive from their home near Los Angeles, thinking it would make for a nice family getaway and a place they could also rent out.

headline: Suns Find the Open Man: It’s Usually Devin Booker
text: PHOENIX — Devin Booker grew up in Grand Rapids, Mich., as a devoted Detroit Pistons fan. He keyed on Ben Wallace’s energy, Chauncey Billups’s steadiness, Rasheed Wallace’s tenacity and Tayshaun Prince’s versatility.

headline: Dozens Die as Another Factory Fire Strikes Bangladesh
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — At least 51 people died in a fire on Thursday evening at an industrial building outside the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, the latest disaster in a country with a long history of unsafe working conditions in its factories.

headline: London Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Murdering Sarah Everard
text: LONDON — A London police officer on Friday pleaded guilty to murdering Sarah Everard, the British woman whose disappearance and killing this year set off a national movement demanding that the authorities do more to address violence against women.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 5: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
text: Update, July 27: Winners from this week have been announced!

headline: The Space Race for Insurers
text: Richard Branson is scheduled to fly into suborbital space this Sunday, nine days ahead of a similar journey by a fellow billionaire, Jeff Bezos. These first flights for the space moguls will also launch without liability insurance.

headline: China moves to spur bank lending to help troubled small businesses.
text: JINAN, China — Faced with gradually slackening economic growth and a direct order for action from China’s cabinet, China’s central bank said Friday that it was taking steps to help the country’s commercial banks lend more money.

headline: Local Recalls, by the Numbers
text: Good morning.

headline: Lionel Messi Tries to Slay His Ghosts
text: As soon as he was back in the changing room, away from the glare of the cameras and the eyes of the world, Lionel Messi got rid of it. He had been presented with the Golden Ball, the prize for the outstanding player in the 2014 World Cup, on the field at the Maracana, and he had accepted it, because it was the decent thing to do.

headline: How to Manage Your Money if Inflation Flares
text: In the end, inflation may not turn out to be a big problem.

headline: The Gift of Financial Education for the New Grad in Your Life
text: With financial adulthood comes a series of firsts — apartments, loan payments and other complex decisions, all made while rent is high and starting paychecks are low.

headline: President Biden Wants to Pour Money Into Infrastructure. Should You?
text: Crucial bridges are decaying. The electricity grid is straining. And climate change, as it worsens storms, floods and wildfires, is intensifying problems. The American Society of Civil Engineers gave the United States a C– in its latest infrastructure report card.

headline: With Inflation Rising, Consider the Humdrum U.S. Savings Bond
text: Inflation has been rising, making more attractive what was formerly considered a humdrum investment: federal savings bonds.

headline: For Some People, Working From Home Sped Up Their Decision to Retire
text: For Mona Janochoski, a chemist who ran a laboratory at 3M in St. Paul, Minn., working from home during the pandemic was the deciding factor.

headline: In Investing, Don’t Sweat the Small Stuff
text: It isn’t worth agonizing over financial decisions that don’t matter.

headline: The Markets Have Prospered. Why Are So Many People Worried?
text: The markets and the economy continue to reap the benefits of the recovery from the pandemic and its associated recession.

headline: Spaceflights for Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos spur a race for insurers, too.
text: Richard Branson is scheduled to fly into suborbital space on Sunday, nine days ahead of a similar journey by a fellow billionaire, Jeff Bezos. These first flights for the space moguls will also launch without liability insurance, the DealBook newsletter reports.

headline: Should an Oasis Be Replaced by Affordable Housing? SoHo Is Divided.
text: In 1990, Allan Reiver stared at the trash-filled lot across the street from his apartment and had a vision.

headline: Plane Crash in Sweden Kills 9, Including 8 Sky Divers
text: A small propeller plane crashed Thursday evening in Sweden soon after taking off from an airport in Orebro, west of Stockholm, killing the nine people onboard — eight sky divers and the pilot.

headline: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
text: Like the series “Lupin,” also on Netflix, this engaging French movie delivers fleet-footed, family-friendly fare that does not talk down to its audience or look as if it’s surreptitiously hawking Happy Meal toys.

headline: In ‘The White Lotus,’ Mike White Takes You on Vacation
text: Last September, the writer-director Mike White checked into a recently reopened but still deserted Four Seasons on Maui. He was the first guest since March. The staff gave him a standing ovation.

headline: The Kid Laroi and Justin Bieber’s Bouncy Plea, and 14 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Biden Will End Detention for Most Pregnant and Postpartum Undocumented Immigrants
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is easing restrictions placed on undocumented people who are pregnant, postpartum or nursing, the latest change in its broader efforts to soften immigration detention policies put in place by former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Murder in a French Mountain Village
text: Novels that explore the effects and aftermath of serial murder, especially over the course of decades, always capture my interest.

headline: The Sea of Marmara, a ‘Sapphire’ of Turkey, Is Choking From Pollution
text: BANDIRMA, Turkey — The Sea of Marmara, fabled for centuries for its blue waters and sparkling fish, laps the shores of Istanbul. Its perfect form inspired a 19th-century historian to describe the ancient city as “a diamond set between two sapphires.”

headline: After Ex-President’s Arrest, South Africa’s Governing A.N.C. Is More Fractured
text: NKANDLA, South Africa — The threat of bloodshed and civil unrest hung in the air for days, but it vanished quickly and painlessly under a star-freckled country sky.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. I think it may be a good weekend for making paella, outside on a grill if you can, trusting in the magical properties of rice, stock, heat and time to bring a new measure of joy into your life. Naturally I have a recipe (above) for you, but you may want to range around and consider other preparations, other techniques, before you cook.

headline: In the U.S., the Virus Is Down, but Not Out
text: The latest news and data from the team tracking the coronavirus.

text: The lessons that dogs can teach us. Also in this edition: a profile of Lil Nas X, and how Indian Americans came to love the Spelling Bee.

headline: The C.D.C. Issues New School Guidance, With Emphasis on Full Reopening
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged schools on Friday to fully reopen in the fall, even if they cannot take all of the steps the agency recommends to curb the spread of the coronavirus — a major turn in a public health crisis in which childhood education has long been a political flash point.

headline: Clutter Can Be Useful
text: Keeping a cluttered house has long been considered a little tacky, a little weak. But now it’s looking very wise.

headline: Here’s what we know about the new schools guidance the C.D.C. issued on Friday.
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released new guidance for schools on Friday, urging them to fully reopen and calling on local districts to tailor their public health measures to local coronavirus data.

headline: Like in ‘Postapocalyptic Movies’: Heat Wave Killed Marine Wildlife en Masse
text: Dead mussels and clams coated rocks in the Pacific Northwest, their shells gaping open as if they’d been boiled. Sea stars were baked to death. Sockeye salmon swam sluggishly in an overheated Washington river, prompting wildlife officials to truck them to cooler areas.

text: An original work of fiction by Andrew Martin.

headline: Mexico will allow a union vote at a General Motors plant after a U.S. complaint.
text: The United States has reached a deal with Mexico to give workers at a General Motors plant in the country the ability to vote on a collective bargaining agreement in “free and democratic conditions.”

headline: Yury Dokhoian, Chess Coach Who Guided Kasparov, Dies at 56
text: Athletes are not the only ones who need coaches. All top chess players have them too. They are often experts at particular elements of the game, or openings, that a player feels he or she needs to work on.

headline: The Education Dept. will wipe out $55 million in student loans for borrowers at 3 institutions.
text: Just weeks after the Education Department erased half a billion dollars in student debt for borrowers defrauded by their schools, the agency said on Friday that it would discharge another $55.6 million for students at three other institutions.

headline: How to Make a Trash Cocktail
text: Before you throw away all those clementine peels, follow these instructions.

headline: How the I.M.F. plans to build a $650 billion fund to fight the pandemic.
text: The International Monetary Fund’s executive board approved a plan to issue $650 billion worth of reserve funds to help troubled countries buy vaccines, finance health care and pay down debt. If approved by the I.M.F.’s board of governors, as is expected, the reserves could become available by the end of August.

headline: Nostalgia, Inc.
text: “We kind of sell people’s childhoods back to them.”

headline: Garland Settles In but Trump Era Still Shadows the Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON — When Attorney General Merrick B. Garland had to decide whether the Justice Department should continue its highly unusual defense of former President Donald J. Trump in a defamation lawsuit, he relied on the studious approach that had served him as a federal judge for more than two decades.

headline: Biden’s order includes 72 initiatives that take aim at very specific practices the White House wants changed.
text: In seeking to protect workers and consumers from what his administration views as the harmful consequences of corporate consolidation, President Biden is enlisting support from regulators across the executive branch in what the White House has described as an overarching, “whole-of-government” effort.

headline: The Menu Evolves for a Muslim Holiday Built Around Food

headline: Chief Guantánamo Prosecutor Retiring Before Sept. 11 Trial Begins

headline: Turning to Ovid in a Moment of Transition
text: OVID’S “METAMORPHOSES”  has served as inspiration for visual artists for hundreds of years, and in 2020 it felt as relevant as ever. It was the first book that I read as I hunkered down in my apartment at the height of the pandemic. Ovid’s cast of human and bestial characters are at the mercy of capricious Gods who constantly change themselves and everything around them into different forms.  These transformations are both beautiful and ghastly, violent and serene — a blurring of boundaries between humans, nature and forces more powerful than ourselves. What inspired me most about the “Metamorphoses” (I read David Raeburn’s classic translation) is how vibrant and visual these stories are, and how Ovid captures human desperation and fragility.  In making these images I wanted to reflect on the idea of becoming something else. Ovid’s physical and emotional landscapes are constantly shifting. I wanted to visualize the feelings we are going through as we start to transform back into our normal lives, re-engaging with ourselves and with nature.

headline: Road Rage, ‘Zipper Merging’ and a Stress-Free Path Through Traffic
text: You’re approaching a construction zone and a sign tells you the left lane will end several miles ahead. Traffic is heavy, but you see an opening and move to the right lane. As you inch along, drivers to your left keep zipping by. Miles ahead, you finally reach the merge point and the left-lane drivers make their move. Your pulse quickens. You pull up tight on the car in front of you and refuse to let anyone in. Are you in the right, or are you fortunate that nothing escalated?

headline: When a No-Pet Policy Isn’t Really a No-Pet Policy
text: Q: I used to love my rent-stabilized apartment, where I’ve lived for a decade, until building management relaxed its strict no-pet policy. I have severe allergies and prefer not to live with other people’s pets. Suddenly, everyone has a dog. Despite my complaints about barking and dog hair trapped in the laundry machines, management insists that the building is not pet friendly. At this point, I’d like to move, but I just signed another two-year lease. Can I break my lease over the weakened pet policy?

headline: How the White Press Wrote Off Black America

Inside, was a brand of brainteaser that I had not solved before: a PandA, or Puns and Anagrams puzzle. PandAs, where have you been all my life?

headline: Privacy Is Still a Victim When Rape Cases Hit the Justice System
text: Things were supposed to be different this time, Brooke thought in disbelief as the police officer demanded that she hand over every scrap of data on her phone to investigators — not because she was suspected of a crime, but because she was the victim of one. Years earlier, a man who Brooke had until then considered a friend pulled her into a London alley, pushed her against a wall, choked her and violently sexually assaulted her. Her fear and humiliation, more than just the invasion of her body, seemed to be his goal. Several times, she said, she broke free, only to have him catch her, throw her back against the wall, and assault her again.

headline: After Years as a Battleground, Investment Boom Lifts Iraqi City
text: RAMADI, Iraq — On the banks of the Euphrates River, the iron beams and bricks are going up for a 20-story luxury hotel with swimming pools, a spa, and restaurants jutting out into the blue-green waters at the edge of the Iraqi city of Ramadi.

headline: On This German Farm, Cows Are in Charge. Or at Least Coequals.
text: BUTJADINGEN, Germany — Tom will lay his head in the lap of anyone who sits down to rub his neck, while Tilda prefers just to nuzzle her young son. Cuddles aren’t really Chaya’s thing, but if she’s in the mood, she’ll play pugnaciously with a bale of hay as if it’s a giant ball.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Director of ‘Showgirls’ Takes On Lesbian Nuns
text: CANNES, France — Forgive them, Father, for they have sinned. Repeatedly! Creatively! And wait until you hear what they did with that Virgin Mary statuette.

headline: Haiti’s Power Vacuum Escalates Kingmakers’ Battle for Control
text: The assassination of Haiti’s president has thrown the nation into disarray, spawned shootouts on the streets and left terrified citizens cowering in their homes. But behind the scenes a bigger, high-stakes battle for control of the country is already accelerating.

headline: Why a Patriotic Education Can Be Valuable
text: I have my doubts about America. As a Catholic, my first loyalty is to a faith that predates and promises to outlast our Republic, that was disfavored for much of our history and may be headed into disfavor once again. American anti-Catholicism is far from the worst evil in this nation’s history, but it still instills a special obligation to take critiques of our Anglo-liberal-Protestant inheritance seriously, whether they come from radicals or traditionalists or both.

headline: The Eclectic Lives BehindAlice Neel’s Portraits
text: My introduction to the painter Alice Neel was a screen print that hung on the living room wall of my grandparents’ home in Woodstock, N.Y. — a provocative portrait of Neel’s pouting granddaughter lounging on a striped chair. That portrait then moved within my family, to Minneapolis, San Francisco and, finally, to my apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan — down the street from where Neel painted and lived —  where it now hangs on my wall.

headline: Death Valley Hits 130 Degrees as Heat Wave Sweeps the West
text: FURNACE CREEK, Calif. — For Gary Bryant, the tenth-of-a-mile walk from his modular home to the air-conditioned restaurant where he was working on Saturday was “quite enough” time outside.

headline: Biden Administration Shows Little Appetite for Haiti’s Troop Request
text: WASHINGTON — Haiti’s request for U.S. troops to help stabilize the country following the assassination of its president presents a difficult choice for President Biden: send forces to aid a neighbor even as he is trying to pare down America’s military footprint overseas, or refrain and risk allowing the chaos unfolding there to escalate into a refugee crisis.

headline: With Wimbledon Win, Ashleigh Barty Continues Mentor’s Work

headline: Texas Man Who Waited Hours to Vote Is Arrested on Charges of Illegal Voting

headline: Egypt Denies Times Report That Officials Sexually Abused Women

headline: Certain Bridge Positions

Shamelessly, he drags us along hand-in-hand behind him down the chutes and up the ladders of dad joke territory, enticing us onward through a thicket of puns by dropping occasional amuse-gueules of ethnic food at strategic points on our route.

headline: In Wimbledon Loss, Karolina Pliskova Sees a Silver Lining

headline: Here’s how to watch and stream the fight.
text: U.F.C. 264 takes place Saturday night at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas. The early preliminary fights start at 6 p.m. Eastern, and the main pay-per-view card will begin at 10 p.m. McGregor and Poirier most likely will not fight until around midnight.

headline: Thomas Cleary, Prolific Translator of Eastern Texts, Dies at 72

headline: Athan Theoharis, Chronicler of F.B.I. Abuses, Dies at 84
text: Athan Theoharis, a pre-eminent historian of the F.B.I. whose indefatigable research into the agency’s formerly unobtainable files produced revelations about decades of civil liberties abuses under the leadership of J. Edgar Hoover, died on July 3 at his home in Syracuse, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: A number of breath-based coronavirus tests are in development around the world.
text: Scientists have long been interested in creating portable devices that can quickly and painlessly screen a person for disease simply by taking a whiff of their breath. But delivering on this dream has proved to be a challenge. Different diseases may cause similar breath changes. Diet can affect the chemicals someone exhales, as can smoking and alcohol consumption, potentially complicating disease detection.

I’d want shovels for clambakes, a rotisserie, a Schwenker and absolutely a wood-burning pizza oven on a trailer to haul behind the van or the house, depending. So this remains a pipe dream.
