When she encounters someone boorish or grating — an insolent waitress, say, or a manspreader on the subway — she seethes with anger, as if allergic to the slightest lapse of etiquette or social politesse. And because Lindy suffers from a rare neurological condition that causes hyperaggressive tendencies and violent impulses, she usually beats these unsuspecting offenders into a bloody mess. She’s like Larry David crossed with The Terminator.

headline: ‘Midnight in the Switchgrass’ Review: Sordid and Derivative
text: “Midnight in the Switchgrass” is the first feature directed by Randall Emmett, whose trademark as a producer — according to a sprawling career overview in New York magazine earlier this year — has been a rash of low-budget movies starring misleadingly top-billed actors like Bruce Willis. “Switchgrass” is superior to those Emmett productions (“Reprisal,” “Survive the Night”), but that bar is on the ground, or even beneath it — buried under the switchgrass, if you will.

headline: ‘Settlers’ Review: Interstellar Colonialism on Mars
text: Billionaires are racing to colonize space, but how might it play out if they were ever to be successful? “Settlers,” a sci-fi thriller from Wyatt Rockefeller (of those Rockefellers) takes a stab at this vision, but succeeds only in telling a clumsy cautionary tale of homesteading and violence on the planet Mars. It would make the most sense for this film to side with Jerry (Ismael Cruz Córdova), a Mars native hoping to reclaim his land. Instead, it paints him as a deranged savage.

headline: ‘Val’ Review: The Iceman Cometh
text: The actor Val Kilmer is not only the subject of “Val,” a documentary directed by Ting Poo and Leo Scott. He also receives a cinematography credit, having shot many of the home movies and video diary entries that give the film its visual texture. More a self-portrait than a profile, “Val” tells the story of a Hollywood career with a candor that stops short of revelation. The tone is personal but not quite intimate, producing in the viewer a warm, slightly wary feeling of companionship.

headline: ‘Charlatan’ Review: The Miracle Worker
text: As the world’s biggest fan of Peter Watkins’s twisted and superb “Edvard Munch,” I harbor a soft spot for filmmakers who muss up the perfectly coifed looks and reassuring habits of biographical films. The great writer-director Agnieszka Holland — a connoisseur of those deemed “difficult” by society — does not disappoint with “Charlatan,” her fictionalized story of the persecuted Czech herbalist Jan Mikolasek.

headline: Robinhood Rewrites the Rules for Going Public
text: Robinhood, which touts its mission as “democratizing finance,” is trying out a new kind of I.P.O.: The online brokerage plans to sell as much as a third of its offering to customers through its app. What could go wrong?

headline: Jerry Lewis, Master of the Congressional Earmark, Dies at 86
text: Jerry Lewis, a powerful House Republican whose largess to his district in California established him as a master of the earmark but led to an investigation of his actions by the Justice Department, died on July 15 at his home in Redlands, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Mercedes-Benz will shift its focus to electric vehicles by 2025.
text: Mercedes-Benz will shift its focus entirely to electric vehicles in 2025 and be prepared to sell nothing but electric cars by 2030, the company said Thursday, adding a caveat that the transition depends on “market conditions.”

headline: When Gender Equality at the Olympics Is Not So Equal
text: TOKYO — For the first time since the founding of the modern Olympics 125 years ago, the Games have nearly reached gender parity.

headline: U.S. withdraws Trump-era requests to seek the death penalty in 7 cases, signaling a shift under Biden.
text: One man was charged in Orlando, Fla., with kidnapping and fatally shooting his estranged wife. Another man was indicted in Syracuse, N.Y., in the armed robbery of a restaurant and the murders of two employees. And a third man was charged in Anchorage with fatally shooting two people during a home invasion.

headline: How Big Is the Bootleg Fire?
text: The 400,000-acre fire is still growing. And it is only 38 percent contained.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Hardy Boys’ and More.
text: I’m a photo editor on the Times’s Culture desk, here are five things I’ve been enjoying lately.

headline: My Mom Doesn’t Want Me to Get the Covid-19 Vaccine. But I Already Did.
text: I am 18 and starting college next month, which will make me the first person in my family to go. I am beyond excited! I worked very hard to get in and cover my costs. Recently, I was notified by health services that I have to show proof of my Covid-19 vaccination to enroll. The problem: My mom has been reading conspiracy theories online and is convinced that the vaccine is unnecessary and will “change my DNA” — whatever that means. She refuses to let me get it. Spoiler: I got vaccinated secretly months ago! (And I wish she would too.) How should I deal with my mom and the school?

headline: Leon Bridges Brings Southern Soul Into the 21st Century
text: Tenacity is baked into Southern soul. It’s there in the grain and determination of the singing, in the patiently rolling grooves, in how its down-to-earth stories unfold. It’s there in the way the music holds on to blues and gospel roots connected to deeper African ancestry. And it’s there in the way the sound persists and adapts through decades, finding new rhythms but still testifying from the heart.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
text: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: A Democratic senator is bottling up Biden’s Customs and Border Protection nominee.
text: WASHINGTON — In an unusual move by a committee chairman in the president’s own party, Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon is refusing to schedule a hearing for President Biden’s nominee to run U.S. Customs and Border Protection until the administration answers questions about the federal response to the unrest in Portland, Ore., last summer.

headline: Communing With Redwoods on the California Coast
text: Summer brings with it a certain set of rites and rituals — and everyone’s are personal and unique. For our weeklong ode to the season, T has invited writers to share their own. Here, the poet Barbara Jane Reyes describes a road trip taken every year down the California coast.

headline: How to Style a Table for a Laid-Back Summer Meal
text: Ask any creative type about their entertaining philosophy and their answer will almost always be that their guests are the most important element of any meal. The rest — the food, the plates, the glasses, the music — is, in a sense, just the dressing. And yet, that doesn’t mean that they don’t also take those trimmings at least somewhat seriously. After all, if your job requires an eye for aesthetics, you’re likely to have an opinion about what lighting is most welcoming, or whether to offer charcuterie instead of crudités. So what are the tried-and-tested practices those people stick to when they have friends over? We asked three Los Angeles natives — Alex Tieghi-Walker, the founder of the gallery and design platform Tiwa Select; Saehee Cho, the chef, stylist and founder of the food subscription service Soon Mini; and the florist Tabia Yapp of the studio Bia Blooms, who also runs the talent agency Beotis — to share their advice for creating a table as stimulating as the company.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s homes are in Chelsea, Ridgewood and Greenwood.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties are four-bedrom houses in Mount Vernon and Chester Township.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: L.A. County’s Public Health Chief Discusses the Mask Mandate
text: Good morning.

headline: I Made the 24-Hour Trek to Tokyo
text: The journey to the Tokyo Olympics was a unique experience. Here’s an inside look.

headline: While England Gambles on ‘Freedom Day,’ Scotland Opts for Caution
text: EDINBURGH, Scotland — “Freedom Day” means something different north of the English border, so it was perhaps not surprising that independence-minded Scotland declined to fall in line earlier this week when Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain lifted virtually all remaining coronavirus restrictions in England.

headline: Haitian leaders jostle for influence with the U.S. after their president’s assassination.
text: The struggle for power in Haiti after the assassination of the country’s president has spilled onto K Street, where rival Haitian politicians, business leaders and interest groups are turning to lobbyists to wage an expensive and escalating proxy battle for influence with the United States.

headline: I Tried 3 New Olympic Sports. Here’s What I Learned.
text: I was standing atop one of the steepest skateboard ramps at the 3rd Lair, a graffiti-walled skate park near my home in Minneapolis. Flanked by my two sons, I peered over the edge and tried to wrap my mind around what I was supposed to do: jump onto my padded knees and slide down the near-vertical slope.

headline: U.S. Olympic Fencer, Accused of Sexual Misconduct, Kept Apart From Team
text: Alen Hadzic is an alternate in the men’s épée event with the United States Olympic fencing team. But while facing accusations of sexual impropriety, which he denies but which remain unresolved, he has been kept apart from his teammates in Tokyo.

headline: How to Channel Your Inner Olympic Coach
text: When the gymnast Simone Biles was heading into the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics, as a gold medal favorite, her coach, Aimee Boorman, noticed the pressure building around her.

headline: How Much Will an Extra Bedroom Cost You in Rent?
text: It’s become increasingly clear over the past year that remote work is not going to fade away when the pandemic does. A survey of 20,000 renters conducted by RentCafé this May found that a third of respondents were working from home and expected to continue, either fully or partially.

headline: Teen Wins Libel Case Against Tommy Robinson, U.K. Far-Right Activist
text: LONDON — Tommy Robinson, a British far-right activist, lost a libel case on Thursday filed by a teenage refugee from Syria who had been filmed being attacked at his school, after Mr. Robinson falsely claimed the boy had himself violently attacked classmates.

headline: In Softball, a Comeback 13 Years in the Making
text: TOKYO — During the 2008 Olympics, Kaleigh Rafter was 21 and representing Canada even though she had not yet finished her college softball career. Still, she thought she probably wouldn’t have a chance to play in the Olympics much longer, because her sport had been voted out from the permanent program.

headline: ‘Ailey’ Review: A Poetic Look at the Man Behind the Dances
text: Too often, the idea of Alvin Ailey is reduced to a single dance: “Revelations.” His 1960 exploration of the Black experience remains a masterpiece, but it also overshadows the person who made it. How can an artist grow after such early success? Who was Alvin Ailey the man?

headline: Jack Antonoff Doesn’t Want to Just Take Up Space
text: To the outside observer, Jack Antonoff might seem like something of a workaholic.

headline: A controversial Alzheimer’s drug has already yielded $2 million in sales.
text: The drug maker Biogen reported on Thursday that its controversial Alzheimer’s drug Aduhelm brought in $2 million in its first few weeks of availability, the first revenue for a treatment that is expected to generate billions of dollars and strain Medicare’s budget within a few years.

headline: Harry deLeyer, 93, Dies; He Saved a Horse and Made Him a Legend
text: Harry deLeyer, a horse trainer and rider who, in what can only be described as a nags-to-riches story, turned an aged, abandoned gelding named Snowman into one of the most acclaimed show horses of all time, died on June 25 in Stanardsville, Va. He was 93.

headline: The House votes to increase the number of visas for Afghans who have helped U.S. troops.
text: The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to expand a visa program for Afghans who are facing retribution for helping American troops and diplomats during the 20-year war in Afghanistan, moving to allow more of them to immigrate to the United States quickly as the Biden administration races to evacuate them.

headline: Floods in China Leave Many Stranded
text: In Zhengzhou, China, many residents were forced to wade through flooded roads after heavy rain engulfed the region with more rain still in the forecast.

headline: Say Yes To Christmas
text: No Christmas can ever be as good as the holidays of childhood. But this episode goes all in and brings the joy, the spontaneity, the sense that anything can happen back to Christmas.

headline: Hoops Recruits Hoping for Scholarships Pick Up Coronavirus Instead
text: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. — The recent surge of coronavirus cases has waylaid the Olympic hopes of dozens of athletes and sidelined Major League Baseball players like Aaron Judge of the Yankees in the last week, so perhaps it is predictable that a Delta variant that has thrived among unvaccinated people would pose a particular threat to the peripatetic world of grass roots youth basketball.

headline: Amazon Ends Use of Arbitration for Customer Disputes
text: Amazon told customers this week that it would no longer require them to resolve their legal complaints involving the technology giant through arbitration, a significant retreat from a strategy that often helps companies avoid liability.

headline: Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago Names New Artistic Directors
text: Steppenwolf Theater Company, an ensemble in Chicago with a track record of premiering critically acclaimed works that land on Broadway, announced its new artistic leadership on Thursday, and for the first time in the company’s decades-long history, that means two people, not one.

headline: A.I. Predicts the Shapes of Molecules to Come
text: For some years now John McGeehan, a biologist and the director of the Center for Enzyme Innovation in Portsmouth, England, has been searching for a molecule that could break down the 150 million tons of soda bottles and other plastic waste strewn across the globe.

headline: Pulling Levers in Exile, Belarus Opposition Leader Works to Keep Her Influence Alive
text: VILNIUS, Lithuania — She has met Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, and President Emmanuel Macron of France. Just this week, she was feted in Washington, where she was received by Secretary of State Antony Blinken.

headline: Harold
text: The story of Harold Washington, the greatest politician you've probably never heard of, and the white backlash that was set off when he became Chicago's first black mayor.

headline: ‘It’s Like Mecca for Judo’
text: TOKYO — Edson Madeira was struggling to summon the right words. Nothing he thought of could quite do justice to the emotions he was feeling.

headline: Senate panel deadlocks over Biden’s nominee to lead the Bureau of Land Management.
text: A heated Senate panel deadlocked along partisan lines on Thursday over the nomination of Tracy Stone-Manning, whom Republicans have accused of lying about her connection to a 1989 tree-spiking incident, to lead the Bureau of Land Management.

headline: In ‘Ted Lasso,’ Juno Temple Makes Nice
text: When Juno Temple first heard from Jason Sudeikis, she assumed that he had messaged the wrong actress.

headline: Obama and Springsteen to Publish Book Based on Their Spotify Series
text: In “Renegades,” a podcast collaboration between Barack Obama and Bruce Springsteen, the former president acknowledged that it was, at a glance, an odd partnership.

headline: Details on F.B.I. Inquiry Into Kavanaugh Draw Fire From Democrats
text: Nearly three years after Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh’s tumultuous confirmation to the Supreme Court, the F.B.I. has disclosed more details about its efforts to review the justice’s background, leading a group of Senate Democrats to question the thoroughness of the vetting and conclude that it was shaped largely by the Trump White House.

headline: A Long-Awaited Museum Opens, With Agony and Ivory
text: BERLIN — For almost 20 years, Werner Kohl has followed the saga of the Humboldt Forum. Like many Germans, he has been watching and listening since 2002, when the government approved a plan for the huge new cultural attraction in Berlin. That’s nearly two decades of debate, protest, overspend and delay.

headline: New Extreme Weather Record? Not So Fast.
text: California’s Death Valley recorded temperatures of 130 degrees Fahrenheit this month, a measurement that could be the highest ever reliably made on Earth.

headline: Ed Atkins and His Mum Are Starring in a Museum Show
text: Of all the strange, attenuated long-distance calls of the last 16 months, the British artist Ed Atkins’s check-in with his mother surely wins a prize for pandemic alienation.

headline: Tips for Making Your Own Ice Cream
text: How to get smooth and delicious homemade ice cream every time.

headline: ‘Old’ Review: They Say Sun Can Age You, but This Is Ridiculous
text: In the opening pages of “Dino,” a 1992 biography of Dean Martin by Nick Tosches, the author cites a haunting Italian phrase: “La vecchiaia è carogna.” “Old age is carrion.”

headline: House Republicans soft-pedal push for Covid vaccinations amid rising infections.
text: House Republican leaders and doctors gathered Thursday morning for a news conference ostensibly to urge Americans to get vaccinated against the coronavirus amid rising infections across the United States, but they used the event to attack Democrats who they said, without proof, had dissembled about the origins of the virus.

headline: What Do Trump and Marinara Have in Common?
text: This article is part of Frank Bruni’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Thursday.

headline: Why Vaccinated People Are Getting ‘Breakthrough’ Infections
text: A wedding in Oklahoma leads to 15 vaccinated guests becoming infected with the coronavirus. Raucous Fourth of July celebrations disperse the virus from Provincetown, Mass., to dozens of places across the country, sometimes carried by fully vaccinated celebrants.

headline: Monsoon rains wash cars off the road in Arizona, with warnings of more flash floods to come.
text: Monsoon season in the Southwestern United States is providing relief to parts of the region that are desperate for any kind of precipitation, but life-threatening flash floods and lightning are also part of the deal.

headline: Dozens of websites go down in a widespread internet outage.
text: Dozens of consumer websites were reported to be offline or slow to load on Thursday afternoon, creating headaches for people trying to gain access to their accounts, but the issues were resolved shortly after.

headline: Pelosi weighs adding Kinzinger, a second anti-Trump Republican, to the Jan. 6 inquiry.
text: Speaker Nancy Pelosi is considering unilaterally appointing a second anti-Trump Republican, Representative Adam Kinzinger of Illinois, to the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, according to two officials familiar with the ongoing discussions.

headline: Reality Rebellion
text: By doubling down on Trump’s Big Lie that the election was stolen, Republicans are making their base angrier, more radical, and more likely to turn to violence.

headline: ‘All the Streets Are Silent’ Review: Hip-Hop and Skateboarding Collide
text: In the late 1980s and early ’90s, long before hypebeasts spent hours waiting for coveted drops outside the Supreme store in SoHo, skaters assembled at a smaller shop on Lafayette Street. There, they would smoke and watch skate videos, listen to music and crack jokes with friends.

headline: The Historian Who Was Not Baffled by the Nazis
text: The Nazi regime had plenty of ways of coercing people without jailing or killing them.

headline: Hemingway: The Male Impersonator
text: The author hid a complex sexuality and a deep trauma behind his outlandish public image.

headline: The Strangely Contentious Lives of the Quincy Adamses
text: John Quincy and Louisa haven’t acquired much of the acclaim that John and Abigail have, but they are an equally fascinating couple.

headline: Can China Replace the West?
text: Westernization — the spread of the West’s influence and values — has rested on much more than its wealth and the military power derived from it.

headline: The Chinese World Order
text: Competition, friction, and testing between the United States and China are unavoidable, probably for decades.

headline: Making Work Accessible
text: The Americans With Disabilities Act was passed 31 years ago. According to this vocational rehabilitation counselor, we need it now as much as ever.

headline: Slaves in the White House
text: The intimately intertwined lives of three Virginian presidents — George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison — their wives and families, and their slaves.

headline: More phone calls, less shopping: how the pandemic changed American lives, down to the minute.
text: The pandemic upended every aspect of daily life last year — work, leisure, even sleep. New government data paints the most detailed picture yet of just how fundamental those disruptions were.

headline: House Republicans Use Call for Vaccinations to Push Inquiry
text: House Republican leaders gathered in Washington, D.C., to urge Americans to get the coronavirus vaccine and accused Democrats, without proof, of covering up the virus’s origins.

headline: What the Fight Over Facebook Misses
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Eleanor in War and Love
text: Eleanor Roosevelt became one of the rare moral leaders of her time  who heeded a principled moral code and sought to raise the aspirations and efficacy of an expanding cadre of followers.

headline: Australian Prime Minister Apologizes for Delayed Vaccine Rollout
text: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia took responsibility for the country’s vaccine program, and apologized for the population’s low vaccination rate. One month ago, only 5 percent of those over age 16 were fully vaccinated.

headline: For Airlines, It’s Looking More Like 2019 Again
text: The aviation recovery is gaining momentum.

headline: The Closed Mind of Mitch
text: A comparison of Senator Mitch McConnell’s memoir and Alec MacGillis’s “The Cynic: The Political Education of Mitch McConnell.”

headline: Building the American Dream
text: What can we learn from the many utopian communities founded in the United States during the first half of the nineteenth century, as well as their extraordinary appeal to earlier Americans?

headline: ‘The Two Noble Kinsmen’ Review: Shakespeare, With a Hint of Celine Dion
text: For its return to live performance, the Drilling Company’s Shakespeare in the Parking Lot series did not rely on a familiar crowd-pleaser from a catalog of greatest hits. It instead chose a deep cut: “The Two Noble Kinsmen.” This play was not even a solo effort for Shakespeare, who shares the credit with John Fletcher, like a Jacobean version of James Patterson sharing authorship with lesser-known collaborators for his thrillers. This new version might also include a third culprit, the director Hamilton Clancy, since it is unlikely that the original contains references to Celine Dion and the ballad “I Will Always Love You.” (We are double-checking with the Folger Shakespeare Library.)

headline: Barbarians Out!
text: Separating fact from myth in understanding Chinese nationalism.

headline: Trash Parrots Invent New Skill in Australian Suburbs
text: You’ve heard of trash pandas: Raccoons raiding the garbage. How about trash parrots?

headline: NASA Releases First Detailed Map of the Insides of Mars
text: The fate of almost everything on Earth’s surface is determined by infernal engines deep below. Mars is no different. Now, thanks to an intrepid robot parked on the Martian surface by NASA in November 2018, scientists have a map of our neighboring world’s geologic abysses, the first ever made of another planet.

headline: Canadian Veterans Fill Void to Help Afghans Who Once Worked With Them
text: OTTAWA — Frustrated by the lack of action by Canada to resettle Afghans who worked for the Canadian government in Afghanistan, some Canadian military veterans are using their own money, time and connections to get them into safer parts of Afghanistan.

headline: The Southeast is soaked and preparing for more rain.
text: An unusually wet spring and early summer across much of the Southeastern United States has soaked the ground and swollen rivers, leading to an increase in flash floods from heavy rains and thunderstorms.

headline: A young Democrat challenges Grassley for Iowa Senate seat, citing his failure to confront the Jan. 6 rioters.
text: Former congresswoman Abby Finkenauer, a 32-year-old Democrat, is jumping into next year’s race against Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, an 87-year-old Republican who was first elected to the seat eight years before she was born.

headline: Chinese Health Officials Shocked by W.H.O. Covid-19 Origin Study
text: Zeng Yixin, the vice minister of the Chinese National Health Commission, dismissed the theory that the coronavirus was man-made in a lab after the World Health Organization proposed to further investigate the labs in Wuhan.

headline: Italy says it will require proof of vaccination or a negative test for many social activities.
text: The Italian government announced on Thursday that it would require people to show proof of vaccination or a recent negative test in order to participate in certain social activities, including indoor dining, visiting museums and attending shows.

headline: As European nations look to national health passes, can the U.S. learn any lessons?
text: With the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreading rapidly and the pace of vaccinations slowing, France and now Italy have chosen to turn to a new tool: ordering people who seek to enter most public venues — including restaurants, movie theaters and sporting venues — to provide health passes.

headline: Prom
text: Stories from prom night, including  in Hoisington, Kan., — a town of about 3,000 — in 2001, when a tornado hit the town while seniors  danced, destroying about a third of it.

headline: Trust Me I’m a Doctor
text: The not-often-talked-about realm of licensing boards, and the disturbing decisions they sometimes make.

headline: New York’s ‘Homecoming’ to Feature a Free Concert in Every Borough
text: In case the other boroughs were jealous of the star-studded concert announced for Central Park in August, the city is giving each one a show to call their own.

headline: New U.S. sanctions aim to punish Cuban forces for crackdowns on protesters.
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration issued new sanctions on Thursday against Cuba’s defense minister and an elite brigade of government security forces over human rights violations during a crackdown on protesters this month.

headline: Milwaukee Needed This Win
text: When Giannis Antetokounmpo signed on with the Milwaukee Bucks in 2013, he was a scrawny 18-year-old rookie from Greece, brimming with untapped potential. The Bucks, meanwhile, were a flailing N.B.A. franchise. Somehow, it was a match made in heaven.

headline: C.D.C. Urges Americans to Get Vaccinated Amid Virus Surge
text: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, warned that the U.S. is at “another pivotal point in this pandemic” as the infectious Delta variant continues to drive the majority of new Covid-19 cases.

headline: A Washington Post reporter sues the paper and its top editors, claiming discrimination.
text: Felicia Sonmez, a Washington Post reporter, filed a discrimination lawsuit against the newspaper and some of its top editors on Wednesday, claiming they had discriminated against her by barring her from covering stories related to sexual assault after she went public as a victim of assault.

headline: Big Money Rules
text: On how and why very rich business men and women have shaped policy in the United States to achieve their personal and ideological goals.

headline: ‘Change is coming’ to streaming, says Jason Kilar, the WarnerMedia chief.
text: AT&T may not want HBO Max anymore, but the streaming platform is gaining traction with customers.

headline: Fauci vs. Rand Paul on Vaccines: No ‘Bromance’ Here
text: To the Editor:

headline: Umbrellas Down
text: Amid China’s new national security law tightening its control over Hong Kong, a return to an episode about the massive anti-government protests there and a check in to see how people are responding.

headline: Should Vaccinated People Start Wearing Masks Again?
text: As the Delta variant spreads among the unvaccinated, many fully vaccinated people are also beginning to worry. Is it time to mask up again?

headline: Looking Back at Inspiring Olympians
text: As the Tokyo Olympics begin, we are looking back at Olympians who died in recent years.

headline: Mississippi asks the Supreme Court to overrule Roe v. Wade.
text: WASHINGTON — Calling Roe v. Wade “egregiously wrong,” Mississippi’s attorney general urged the Supreme Court on Thursday to do away with the constitutional right to abortion and to sustain a state law that bans most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy.

headline: Live Webinar: Teaching With Learning Network Contests
text: This webinar will introduce educators to the nine contests, as well as additional monthly and weekly challenges, that The Learning Network will be running during the 2021-22 school year. Through writing, photography, podcast production and more, these contests give students an opportunity to exercise voice and choice and to create work for an authentic audience.

headline: U.K. Leaders Hail a Return to Normal; Their Phone App Disagrees
text: LONDON — Gas stations closed, garbage collection canceled and supermarket shelves stripped bare of food, water and other essential goods.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: The Music Scene in This Brooklyn Neighborhood Is Here to Stay
text: One July Sunday, just off Newkirk Plaza in Brooklyn — between the yellow facade of a laundromat and the red awning of a bodega — the mellow strains of a saxophone floated over a crowd of about 150. The Haitian jazz guitarist Eddy Bourjolly introduced the song “Complainte Paysanne,” and the band serenaded the street.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: In 1964, the last time Japan hosted the Games, the country was riding high on postwar optimism and economic development. This year, the Games are essentially closed to the public, and many Tokyo residents are fleeing a scorching-hot city that has spent weeks under a state of emergency.

headline: Striking Frito-Lay Workers Demand Better Hours
text: Hundreds of workers who make Cheetos, Lays potato chips and other popular snack foods at a Frito-Lay plant in Topeka, Kan., have been on strike since July 5, protesting what they call “suicide shifts” and other poor working conditions.

headline: Tear Down the Restaurant Sheds Before It’s Too Late
text: Like most everyone, I love New York City’s Open Restaurants program. Started in June 2020, it allows restaurants to serve customers on sidewalks and in the street without having to pay rent or fees. As a result, owners of restaurants across the city erected improvised sheds that enabled them to stay afloat during the pandemic; allowed us to eat, drink and socialize safely; and made New York feel more like New York at a time when we sorely needed it.

headline: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, outlines plans to confront the ‘Havana Syndrome.’
text: The C.I.A. is stepping up efforts to confront the cause and effects of mysterious sonic incidents, believed to be attacks, that have injured U.S. officials, by increasing medical staff and assigning an agency veteran who hunted Osama bin Laden, the agency’s director, William J. Burns, said in an interview on Thursday.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: Brace yourself! We have thrillers for you this week, from S. A. Cosby’s revenge novel “Razorblade Tears” to Christine Mangan’s fevered “Palace of the Drowned,” about the intense and possessive friendship between two women. Matt Bell’s “Appleseed” offers an apocalyptic vision of climate change. Zakiya Dalila Harris’s “The Other Black Girl” takes readers inside the world of New York publishing. Dean Jobb’s “The Case of the Murderous Dr. Cream” revisits the true story of a Victorian-era serial killer. And there are thrills of another kind to be found in the life of Fernando Pessoa, the great Portuguese writer who left behind a body of ingenious work under a tangled thicket of assumed names and identities; in “Pessoa,” the biographer Richard Zenith resurrects them all.

headline: 31 Children Test Positive for Coronavirus at Summer Camp
text: The outbreak at Camp Pontiac, a sleep-away camp in upstate New York, started in the girls’ dormitories. Nurses, worried that young campers were showing symptoms of Covid-19, began administering tests. Last Saturday, one came back positive.

headline: A Murder ‘Solved’ in 4 Hours Sent the Wrong Man to Prison for 23 Years
text: It was around 6 p.m. on Good Friday in April 1996, and Shdell Lewis was walking with a close friend outside his home on Staten Island when a gunman wearing a black jacket and a Wu-Tang Clan hat walked past, turned around and opened fire. Mr. Lewis was hit several times, collapsed nearby and later died at a hospital.

headline: The West Is Burning. Covid Is Surging. U.S. Politics Are Stagnant.
text: The sirens have gotten pretty hard to ignore.

headline: ‘A Recipe for Catastrophic Fire’: How an Oregon Blaze Became the Nation’s Largest
text: Follow our live coverage of extreme weather and climate change.

headline: ‘I’ll Never Forget You’: Veterans Push to Get Afghan Partners in War to the U.S.
text: EDGEWATER, Md. — In a grainy video chat, Zak shared the latest from his embattled province in Afghanistan, an update as grim as it was commonplace. “The Taliban left a note at my house last night. They said, ‘Surrender tonight or we will kill you,’” he recounted in a tone more resigned than terrified.

headline: National Weather Service Will Send Mobile Alerts for ‘Destructive’ Thunderstorms
text: Thunderstorms that the National Weather Service deems “destructive” will trigger an emergency alert on smartphones as part of the agency’s efforts to get people to protect themselves during severe weather, the agency said Thursday.

headline: Vaccinations, Bootleg Fire, Tokyo Games: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Climate Crisis Turns World’s Subways Into Flood Zones
text: Follow our live coverage of extreme weather and climate change.

headline: Harry Rosenfeld, Who Saw News in a ‘Third-Rate Burglary,’ Dies at 91
text: Harry M. Rosenfeld, who injected his brash brand of journalism into The Washington Post, where he oversaw the two reporters who transformed a local crime story into the national Watergate corruption scandal that toppled the Nixon administration, died on July 16 at his home in upstate Slingerlands, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: Jewish Burial Records Among Items Seized by U.S. Authorities
text: A historic register of Jewish burial records from the modern-day Romanian city of Cluj-Napoca  is among artifacts that have been recovered as part of a seizure by authorities in New York who plan to return the objects to their communities of origin.

headline: Argentina Formally Recognizes Nonbinary People, a Latin American First
text: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina has become the first country in Latin America to officially recognize gender nonbinary people, who can now choose to have their gender marked as an X on their national identity documents and passports if they do not identify as either female or male.

headline: Where Is Biden’s Climate Change ‘Revolution’?
text: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: ‘Not Out of the Woods’: C.D.C. Issues Warning to the Unvaccinated
text: WASHINGTON — The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned on Thursday that the United States was “not out of the woods yet” on the pandemic and was once again at a “pivotal point” as the highly infectious Delta variant ripped through unvaccinated communities.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: The director of the C.D.C., Dr. Rochelle Walensky, issued a blunt new warning about the virus today, calling the Delta variant “one of the most infectious respiratory viruses” known to scientists, and said that the U.S. was at “another pivotal point” in the pandemic.

headline: Should Only the Little People Pay Taxes?
text: I yield to no one when it comes to cynicism about politicians who see tax cuts for the rich as the answer to every problem. Indeed, the claim that tax cuts can perform magic is a prime case of a zombie idea — an idea kept alive, despite overwhelming evidence against it, because its survival serves the interests of wealthy donors.

headline: How Racist Is America?
text: One question lingers amid all the debates about critical race theory: How racist is this land? Anybody with eyes to see and ears to hear knows about the oppression of the Native Americans, about slavery and Jim Crow. But does that mean that America is even now a white supremacist nation, that whiteness is a cancer that leads to oppression for other groups? Or is racism mostly a part of America’s past, something we’ve largely overcome?

headline: After Recent ‘Heat Dome,’ Washington Issues Warning Not to Eat Raw Shellfish
text: Washington State health officials have urged consumers not to eat locally harvested raw oysters and other shellfish after an outbreak of intestinal disease caused by bacteria that multiplied rapidly after a recent “heat dome” baked the Pacific Northwest.

headline: Democrats’ Divide on Voting Rights Widens as Biden Faces Pressure
text: WASHINGTON — A quiet divide between President Biden and the leaders of the voting rights movement burst into the open on Thursday, as 150 organizations urged him to use his political mettle to push for two expansive federal voting rights bills that would combat a Republican wave of balloting restrictions.

headline: How the HIPAA Law Works and Why People Get It Wrong
text: As September beckons people back to the office and the highly infectious Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads rapidly across the country, workplaces are navigating a range of challenges, including whether to require employees to be vaccinated or to reimpose mask mandates.

headline: Need a Last-Minute Passport Appointment? You Can’t Book It Online.
text: People who need to renew their passports immediately will not be allowed to book last-minute appointments online, the U.S. State Department announced on Thursday.

headline: Representative Hank Johnson is arrested while protesting on Capitol Hill.
text: Representative Hank Johnson, Democrat of Georgia, was among a group of protesters arrested on the Capitol complex on Thursday while demonstrating for voting rights and against the filibuster in the Senate. The arrest came one week after the chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus was arrested by U.S. Capitol Police, also while demonstrating for voting rights.

headline: A veteran police chief has been tapped to lead the Capitol Police, half a year after the Jan. 6 riot.
text: J. Thomas Manger, a veteran police chief of departments in the Washington, D.C., region, has been hired to lead the United States Capitol Police, the board that oversees the agency announced on Thursday.

headline: Fred Zalokar, Marathoner Who Took On Mountains, Is Found Dead in Yosemite
text: An accomplished endurance athlete who competed in ultramarathons and listed summiting several of the world’s tallest mountains among his feats was found dead this week in Yosemite National Park in California, the National Park Service said.

headline: An Officer Was Taunted and Spit At. Now He Faces Criminal Charges.
text: A New York police sergeant was charged on Thursday with attacking two handcuffed suspects in separate arrests, punching one in the face when he was in a cell and kneeling on the back of another who was shouting “I can’t breathe” from a subway station floor.

headline: Justice Dept. Seeks to Curb Illegal Gun Trafficking
text: CHICAGO — The Justice Department on Thursday began putting in place a plan to reduce violent crime in the nation’s largest cities, detailing the work of five federal strike forces aimed at disrupting illegal gun traffickers who flood urban streets with illicit firearms.

headline: Simone Biles has her own emoji, and it suits her well.
text: Simone Biles now has an emoji befitting her status.

headline: Spot of Coffee
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Ponder this while you solve Michael Hawkins’s puzzle: Why do we have tougher crossword puzzles at the end of the solving week? I mean, other than the fact that the order of difficulty was established long ago, and clarified by crosswords editor Will Shortz.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.S. ‘Not Out of the Woods Yet,’ Says C.D.C.’s Chief
text: “This is like the moment in the horror movie when you think the horror is over and the credits are about to roll. And it all starts back up again.”

headline: Corrections: July 23, 2021
text: An article on Thursday about Martine Moïse’s return to Haiti after being wounded in the attack that killed her husband, President Jovenel Moïse, misstated Ms. Moïse’s remarks about her husband’s funeral. As the article correctly pointed out elsewhere, she said that her family would pay for the funeral and that public funds would not be sought. She did not say that public money would be used.

headline: Greg Knapp, a Jets Assistant Coach, Dies at 58
text: Greg Knapp, the Jets’ passing-game specialist, died on Thursday from injuries he sustained while being struck by a car as he rode a bicycle in California last weekend. He was 58.

headline: The Delta Variant Taught Me to Waste Time. And I’m Grateful.
text: Instead of jogging or swimming or surfing, my usual lockdown exercise options, I went for a walk the other day with the explicit goal of wasting time. Strolling along Sydney’s eastern coastline, I had no destination in mind, no schedule to keep, and I stopped along the way.

headline: When a Summer Hookup Lasts 12 Years, It’s Time to Reassess
text: Albert and I got together the old-fashioned way: A mutual friend introduced us at a summer house party. We were hovering near a kitchen counter laden with red Solo cups, handles of Hennessey, bottles of mixed fruit juices and a spread of Blow Pops.

headline: The Olympics Rely On, but Don’t Support, Black Girl Magic
text: For better or worse, the Tokyo Olympics are finally here. And that means an extraordinary burden will fall again on the shoulders of a single group of athletes: Black women.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Italy will require people to show proof of Covid-19 vaccination or a recent negative test to dine indoors, visit museums and attend shows, among other social activities, following steps taken by France and Israel.

headline: Tense Funeral for Haiti Leader Exposes Rifts, and U.S. Delegation Departs Early
text: CAP-HAÏTIEN, Haiti — Heckled by protesters and surrounded by phalanxes of heavily armed guards, foreign diplomats and Haitian politicians attended the funeral of Haiti’s assassinated president on Friday, a tense event that laid bare a fractured nation’s problems instead of providing an opportunity for healing.

headline: Germany Is in Shock. Its Politicians Are on Autopilot.
text: BERLIN — Germany, unlike the United States, doesn’t really have a history of natural disasters. Blessed with a moderate climate and fortunate geography, the country knows little of hurricanes, strong earthquakes or heavy rain.

headline: Seth Meyers Demands His Own Ben & Jerry’s Flavor
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: How a Frontline Nurse Trained for the Olympics in a Time of Pandemic
text: As many of her competitors spent their days preparing for the Olympics, Joan Poh spent much of the past year helping Singapore fight the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The bubble bursts: New Zealand suspends quarantine-free travel from Australia.
text: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand ordered a pause on quarantine-free travel from Australia for at least eight weeks, citing coronavirus surges caused by the Delta variant that have left more than half of Australia under lockdown.

headline: They resist being vaccinated despite living in one of New York City’s virus hot spots.
text: On Staten Island’s South Shore, the sole mass vaccination site — an elementary school’s gymnasium — closed down this week, and was replaced by a vaccination van that has been giving fewer than 10 shots a day.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, July 23, 2021
text: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Case for Scheduling Everything
text: Before the pandemic emptied offices and turned dining tables into desks, getting a midday haircut or heading out for 5 p.m. therapy could involve a bit of clandestine choreography: clearing one’s schedule of meetings, finding a friend to cover, then slipping out while the boss was away.

headline: She Said Yes. Twice.
text: Damon Holick could hardly believe it when his mother called in April of 2021 to say she thought she saw a photo of him on television proposing to Erica Willard. She was right. The photo of Mr. Holick on one knee in front of Ms. Willard at the pier in the Woodlands, Texas, at Hughes Landing was sent to a TV station in Houston by a woman who just happened to see the proposal in action. The sweet capture quickly went viral.

headline: Forget Mask Mandates. Vaccines Are the Only Answer for Fighting Covid-19.
text: It’s not often that I say this as a conservative, but Mayor Bill de Blasio is absolutely correct to reject calls for a renewed indoor mask mandate and to refuse to consider renewed lockdowns in New York City in light of the emergence of the Delta variant. “A mask doesn’t arrest the progress of the variant,” Mr. de Blasio said, explaining how following the science led him to be reluctant to reinstitute the mandate this week. “Vaccination does.” This holds true not just for New York City: reinstituting mask mandates and lockdowns would be a mistake nationwide as well.

headline: Advertisements for the Otherworldy
text: Science Fiction was extraordinarily popular in the 1940s and 1950s — and so were books about U.F.O.s. Coverage of mysterious objects in the night sky was plentiful in The Times, too. On July 6, 1947, the front page featured an article headlined “Flying Saucers Mystify Experts; May Be Prank of Nature.” Two days later, a follow-up appeared, also on the front page, with a more provocative headline: “‘Disks’ Soar Over New York, Now Seen Aloft in All Colors.” It should perhaps come as no surprise that those years saw the Book Review filled with ads looking to sate this interest in the extraterrestrial and dystopian.

headline: The Life-Changing Trip to the Principal’s Office
text: Mason McDowell went to a Wichita, Kan., job fair in March 2020 expecting his hands to get sweaty and his throat to go dry for the usual reasons. The competition was considerable, and he hoped to walk out with an offer to put his elementary school teaching credentials to use.

headline: Biden Is Asking for $4 Trillion. Congress Shouldn’t Give It to Him.
text: Prices are rising rapidly, and elevated inflation is likely to remain through at least the next year. Congress shouldn’t make matters worse by signing a $4 trillion check for President Biden’s economic plan, which Democratic leaders are looking to push through even without Republican support.

headline: How Blue Cities Became So Outrageously Unaffordable
text: Joe Biden’s economic agenda is centered on a basic premise: The United States needs to build. To build roads and bridges. To build child care facilities and car-charging stations. To build public transit and affordable housing. And in doing so, to build a better future for everyone.

headline: The Supreme Court Needs to Be Cut Down to Size
text: On Tuesday, the Presidential Commission on the Supreme Court of the United States sat for its third public meeting. Formed in April by executive order, the 36-member commission exists to hear arguments for and against Supreme Court reform and to analyze and appraise the merits of specific proposals.

headline: One by One, African Countries Dismantle Colonial-Era Death Penalty Laws
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Lawmakers in Sierra Leone voted unanimously on Friday to abolish the death penalty, a momentous step that made the West African country the 23rd on the continent to prohibit capital punishment.

headline: There Has Never Been a Better Time to Have a Headache
text: I have headaches. Not the low-grade, annoying, “I’ve got a headache” sort of headaches. I get those, too. Most everyone does, and they are a drag.

headline: ‘The Hot Doctor’ Finds a Life Partner Close to Home
text: It took him nine months. But on a rainy morning in March 2016, in the Rittenhouse neighborhood of Philadelphia, the man known as “the hot doctor” by all the girls on the block finally asked out the girl he apparently had noticed a few months after she had moved into the brownstone just one door down from his.

headline: They Had Some Experience With Wedding Planning
text: In August 2019, Anna Freimuth, the daughter of Matthew Freimuth, was unofficially wed to one of her stuffed animals, a plush pink dog that has no name. Mr. Freimuth and his then-boyfriend, Adam Rogers, performed the ceremony, which was held on the back deck of a rented house in East Hampton, N.Y. Mr. Freimuth and Mr. Rogers were also the de facto planners: They bought flowers for the occasion, and they put together a playlist for post-ceremony dancing. The faux nuptials were held at the request of Anna, then 7.

headline: Invest in China, but Without Illusions
text: Americans have good reasons to be wary of investing in China. It’s easy to get caught up in the headlines and go no further.

headline: Slow and Steady to the Altar
text: Connor May originally planned to propose to Kaitlin Brown, his girlfriend of three years at the time, after they had finished swimming 1.2 miles, cycling 56 miles and running 13.1 miles together. Competing in a half-Ironman triathlon, he thought, would be an important milestone and a fitting preamble to their engagement.

headline: Sixty Guests at a ‘Six-Word’ Wedding
text: The entire world, it seemed, knew that Taylor Hollenkamp had received a marriage proposal.

headline: How to Survive a Plague, Part 2
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Songs to Accompany a Dreamy Summer Dinner Party
text: When creating a playlist for a dinner party, it can be useful to think ahead and imagine the end of the night — should things conclude with whiskey and delayed goodbyes on the couch or with dancing into the wee hours? Because music, after all, can not only set the tone but also help determine the entire trajectory of an evening. Where to begin, though? Curating the perfect lineup can feel like a daunting task, and even music obsessives can fall into ruts and benefit from others offering up song suggestions. Recently, we asked a range of artists, musicians and other creative types to do just that, and to share a few tips on putting your selections together.

headline: After Two Decades and a DNA Test, Charges Are Dropped in Georgia Killings
text: Last year, nearly two decades after Dennis Perry was convicted of fatally shooting two people in the vestibule of a small church in Camden County, Ga., two hair samples — collected 35 years apart — tipped the scales in his favor.

headline: Love at First Photo Sighting
text: Alexandra Giniger recalled the night in her Brooklyn apartment in November 2016 when Bryan Scotland sat beside her, eating pizza on a mattress he had borrowed from a friend.

headline: An iMessage Almost Cost Them an ‘I Do’
text: Five years ago, the trajectories of Elizabeth Svokos and Kervin Ray Briones Morales’s lives were almost altered by a tech glitch.

headline: Help! I’m Traveling to Europe. All the Requirements Are a Dizzying Mess.
text: I know that vaccinated Americans are not required to quarantine when visiting France, but are they required to take a Covid test — either going there or returning home? And although I updated my Clear app to show that I have been vaccinated, I don’t know who is responsible for looking at it: Is it the airline when you check in, an officer when you go through security or someone on the ground when you land? Bob

headline: They Live in an N.Y.C. Virus Hot Spot. But They Won’t Get Vaccinated.
text: On Staten Island’s South Shore, the sole mass vaccination site — an elementary school’s gymnasium — closed down this week, and was replaced by a vaccination van that has been giving fewer than 10 shots a day.

headline: Their First Kiss Missed the Mark, But Their Connection Was Spot On
text: Ryan Tsou’s first attempt at kissing Amy Lee was as far-off the mark as Mr. Tsou himself when it came to the kind of men Ms. Lee was used to dating.

headline: What Happens When Your Waiter Can’t Afford Rent
text: If LaToya Flood had her way, she would hire an additional five to seven employees at Ruby Mae Soul Food Restaurant, which she has operated for three years in Kingston, N.Y. With her business open now just on Fridays and Saturdays, Ms. Flood and her sole employee, her mother, prepare all week for what could be a thriving, full-time business.

headline: How (and Why) the Metro Desk Photographed 115 Service Workers
text: In January, Jeffrey Furticella, photo editor for The Times’s Metro desk, read a staggering figure. The previous month, when a second wave of the coronavirus in New York prompted new restrictions on bars and restaurants, more than 11,000 service industry workers in the city were laid off. It was one last punch to the sector in a year when 200,000 hospitality jobs disappeared.

headline: Testing Britney Spears: Restoring Rights Can Be Rare and Difficult
text: Her voice quaking with anger and despair, the pop star Britney Spears has asked repeatedly in court to be freed from the conservatorship that has controlled her money and personal life for 13 years. What’s more, she asked the judge to sever the arrangement without making her undergo a psychological evaluation.

headline: What Gurbir Grewal Learned as the Nation’s First Sikh Attorney General
text: Gurbir S. Grewal did not seek out the powerful role at the Securities and Exchange Commission that he is planning to start on Monday.

headline: What Improves the Chances of Solving a Murder?
text: “The First 48,” a documentary on A&E about solving murders, has produced more than 450 episodes since its 2004 debut. The show’s title sequence tells us homicide detectives’ chances of solving a murder are “cut in half if they don’t get a lead within the first 48 hours.”

headline: A Foreign Agent in Trump’s Inner Circle?
text: Once upon a time, it would have been huge news if the chairman of the former president’s inaugural committee was indicted on charges of acting as an agent of a foreign power.

headline: How an Environmental Watchdog of the Hudson River Spends Sundays
text: For more than two decades, John Lipscomb has been the eyes and ears of New York’s waterways. As the patrol boat captain for Riverkeeper, an environmental nonprofit, he travels approximately 5,750 miles every year. Along with First Mate Batu, a 3-year-old yellow Lab, the duo polices the entire Hudson River, from New York Harbor to north of Troy. They also monitor the Gowanus Canal and Newtown Creek, two highly polluted bodies of water in Brooklyn undergoing federal cleanups.

headline: Burned by Hot Housing Market, Some Buyers Back Off
text: The first house was in Midvale, Utah — a three-bedroom, just over 2,100 square feet, listed for $479,000. Rob Ettaro and his girlfriend, Kaliana Veros, who had moved from western New York to Salt Lake City, drawn by career opportunities and the stunning scenery of the Wasatch Range, decided to make an offer.

headline: She Heard His Voice and Found Her Soul Mate
text: Natasha Grano and Michael Graziano said their intimate wedding with four guests on June 5 was “elegant and powerful.” Equally special was the ceremony a day after, attended by thousands on the social media app Clubhouse, where their closest confidants gather.

headline: Stumbling Upon Greatness: Discovering Sergio Larrain
text: Back in 1977, working in my first journalism job, I picked up a couple of LPs that caught my eye on the “slush pile” of publicists’ mailings, took them home, and heard with amazement the intoxicating music of the English singer-songwriter Nick Drake, who died in 1974. Obsessed, I traveled to England and wrote the first full-length magazine article on him in this country, thrilled that I could spread the good news.

headline: How Tech Won the Pandemic and Now May Never Lose
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In April 2020, with 2,000 Americans dying every day of Covid-19, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive and the world’s richest man, announced he was focusing on people rather than profits. Amazon would spend about $4 billion in the next few months “providing for customers and protecting employees,” he said, wiping out the profit the retailer would have made without the virus.

headline: Crypto Nomads: Surfing the World for Risk and Profit
text: It is just after midnight in Hong Kong, and Sam Bankman-Fried stares at the trading data on his six monitors, watching a global cryptocurrency crash happening in real time.

headline: ‘I Feel Conflicted’: Crypto’s Offshore Trading Moguls Talk Shop
text: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, and Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, the world’s largest crypto platform, have made fortunes with products that are off limits to nonprofessional U.S. investors.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Protect Sex Workers? Depends on Whom You Ask.
text: TS Candii first traded sex at age 13, after she was forced out of her family home in Tennessee. To survive, she decided to lie about her age, she said, taking refuge with a group of older transgender women who became her mentors. They taught her how to support herself through sex, warning that she would have few options in the formal economy, which is often intolerant of trans people.

headline: What to Do This Summer: Lower Manhattan
text: The big toe of Lower Manhattan dips into the water where the East River meets the Hudson, outlining a harbor rich with attractions. Three inviting neighborhoods in the area — Battery Park City, TriBeCa and the South Street Seaport — are easily reached by public transportation and offer breezy marinas, ample green space, destination restaurants and a multitude of art galleries. These days, out-of-towners are in scant evidence along the waterfront and Wall Streeters just a mere trickle, apparently in no rush to return to office buildings.

headline: A Skateboarder’s Secret Grind
text: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. — Nyjah Huston was driving his Mercedes coupe well past the speed limit between his $3 million house overlooking the Pacific Ocean and his private indoor skatepark where he was training for the Olympics.

headline: Men Who Beat Hong Kong Protesters in Mob Attack Are Sentenced to Prison
text: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong judge has sentenced seven men to prison for their roles in a 2019 mob attack on unarmed people in a subway station, which shocked the city and injured dozens, including pro-democracy protesters.

headline: Here’s what to expect during the opening ceremony.
text: Follow our live coverage of the Olympics.

headline: ‘A gift from God’: Greece enlists the church in its vaccine drive.
text: The message from Greek officials is the same as it is from governments around the world: get vaccinated, get vaccinated, get vaccinated.

headline: Summer Camps and Virus Outbreaks: What to Know
text: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: A Crazy Celine Dion Movie and New Accounts of Trump’s Final Year: The Week in Narrated Articles
text: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Putting a Price on Pollution
text: Extreme weather across Europe, North America and Asia is highlighting a harsh reality of science and history: The world as a whole is neither prepared to slow down climate change nor live with it.

headline: Chicago will require masks in school this fall, regardless of vaccination status.
text: Chicago Public Schools will require everyone to wear masks in school buildings when the new academic year starts, regardless of their vaccination status, according to guidelines the school system released on Thursday.

headline: Puzzled by the parade of nations? Here’s how the order is chosen.
text: Where is the United States marching in the parade of nations in the opening ceremony? If this is in alphabetical order, why is Yemen coming right after the A’s? And why is Russia getting a prime position?

headline: Boosting Vaccinations
text: Vaccine mandates are controversial. They’re also effective.

headline: This opening ceremony has had its share of controversy.
text: Follow our live coverage of the Tokyo Olympics.

headline: ‘Playing With Sharks’ Review: Intrepid Journeys Undersea
text: The chipper documentary “Playing with Sharks” celebrates the life of the diver Valerie Taylor, who dedicated her career to marine photography and conservation. The film (on Disney+) plunges into Valerie’s work with sharks, which she and her husband Ron Taylor captured in a trove of close-range undersea footage.

headline: ‘Woodstock 99: Peace, Love and Rage’ Review: How a Festival Went Wrong
text: It is mildly surprising that it took so long for a documentary about the 1999 edition of the Woodstock music festival to be made. After all, this was an epic, epoch-defining debacle that deserves more scrutiny than, say, the Fyre Festival, a preposterous fiasco from 2017 that crashed before actually happening yet has already prompted two films about it.

headline: ‘Stuntman’ Review: A Big Leap
text: “I’m the face you never see,” Eddie Braun says, even though he’s racked up more than 250 film and TV credits. Braun’s hot rod greaser hairdo and battered jumpsuits signify that he’s either a “Stuntman,” hence the title of Kurt Mattila’s simplistic documentary, or an aging astronaut pressed into service for one last mission, which also turns out to be close to the truth. Now in his 50s, Braun is bored of barrel-rolling exploding cars, as are his wife and four kids whose ho-hum response to his latest fireball implies they think of their pops as indestructible.

headline: ‘Black Widow’ | Anatomy of a Scene
text: The director Cate Shortland narrates a sequence from her film featuring Scarlett Johansson and Florence Pugh.

headline: Watch Scarlett Johansson and Florence Pugh Spar in ‘Black Widow’
text: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Meet the Crypto Nomads
text: Some of the world’s most important cryptocurrency exchanges — platforms like Binance and FTX — are not based in the United States. Yet their founders grew up in North America and trace their professional roots to Wall Street.

headline: Read the document
text: A $600,000 settlement was reached after an investigation by the New York State attorney general into Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich’s hospitality group detailed a culture of widespread sexual harassment and retaliation.

headline: Buy My House, But I’m Taking the Toilet
text: In a housing market desperately short on inventory, with prices spiraling toward the heavens, sellers can demand almost anything these days. They can even take the toilets.

headline: Olympic protesters made themselves heard during the opening ceremony.
text: There are no fans inside Tokyo’s Olympic Stadium for the opening ceremony. But hundreds of people are outside, including protesters whose voices and noisemakers can be heard echoing throughout the stadium during every pause in programming.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 7: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
text: Welcome to Week Seven of our 12th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: $600,000 Sexual Harassment Settlement Reached in Batali & Bastianich Case
text: An investigation into the once-towering Manhattan restaurant business built by the chef Mario Batali and his former partner Joe Bastianich revealed a sexualized culture so rife with harassment and retaliation that it violated state and city human rights laws, the New York State attorney general, Letitia James, announced on Friday.

headline: Russia isn’t at the Games. Yet there it is.
text: Russia has been banned from the Games because of its state-sponsored doping program.

headline: Pita the Tongan is back for a third opening ceremony.
text: Pita Taufatofua became an overnight sensation five years ago when he marched shirtless and in a traditional Tongan costume at the opening ceremony of the 2016 Rio Games, and again at the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea.

headline: The True Value of Gold
text: Daniel Alves has seen it all, done it all. He has won league titles in three countries, picked up nine cups, conquered Europe with his club and South America with his country. He has 41 major honors to his name, officially making him the most decorated player in history. But still, when André Jardine asked him to take on one last job, his eyes lit up.

headline: A King Arthur Rarity Is an Apt Way to Return to the Opera
text: In the third act of Ernest Chausson’s opera “Le Roi Arthus” (“King Arthur”), Guinevere asks Lancelot, “United in love, united in sin, will we also be joined in death?”

headline: A Painting or an NFT of It: Which Will Be More Valuable?
text: The British artist Damien Hirst, best known for putting a shark in a tank of formaldehyde, has gotten on the NFT bandwagon.

headline: A Vogue Legend, Still Enlarging Circles of Pleasure
text: When Archie Burnett walks onto a dance floor, he tends to take it over.

headline: The ‘Californization’ of the Olympics
text: Good morning.

headline: The U.S. athletes are here. Well, some of them.
text: Follow our live coverage of the Tokyo Olympics.

headline: Ralph Lauren adds wearable tech to the opening ceremony’s fashion mix.
text: Ralph Lauren has been outfitting Team USA with their formal looks since 2008. The approach is pretty much always red-white-and-blue preppy classicism, and this year’s outfits don’t look much different (check out those striped belts and ascots!) but there’s actually a secret sauce in the mix, and it’s a lot cooler.

headline: Scientists Finish the Human Genome at Last
text: Two decades after the draft sequence of the human genome was unveiled to great fanfare, a team of 99 scientists has finally deciphered the entire thing. They have filled in vast gaps and corrected a long list of errors in previous versions, giving us a new view of our DNA.

headline: Telfar Clemens designed the Liberian outfits.
text: Formal Olympian wardrobes are rarely “cool” — and rarely available to smaller countries with less promotional muscle. But this year Liberia changed that narrative.

headline: Lil Nas X in the Pop Stratosphere
text: “Old Town Road,” remember? Were we ever so young?

headline: Tig Notaro’s ‘Drawn’ Explores Strange New Worlds: Animated Ones
text: One day during the production of her new, animated stand-up special, Tig Notaro was presented with a rough illustrated version of an anecdote about her double mastectomy. In the bit, Notaro ponders what her doctors might have done with her discarded breasts after the surgery she underwent following a 2012 cancer diagnosis. What if, she asks, the remains had been tossed in a Hollywood dumpster? Might they have been left for rodents to play tug of war with?

headline: In ‘The Pursuit of Love,’ Looking for Liberation, Too
text: If you ask Emily Mortimer, there’s something inherently rock ‘n’ roll about Nancy Mitford’s 1945 novel “The Pursuit of Love.”

headline: Jill Biden cheers for the American athletes in Tokyo.
text: Jill Biden, the first lady, clapped and waved on Friday as a contingent of masked American athletes joined the opening ceremony of the Summer Olympics in Tokyo.

headline: The music for the athletes was a parade of video game hits.
text: Is some of the music during the parade of nations reminding you of a climactic battle you once fought, or perhaps a title screen you clicked through a hundred times?

headline: Montana’s Famed Trout Under Threat as Drought Intensifies
text: HELENA, Mont. — Few places in the world rival Montana’s fly fishing, and the state’s cold, clear mountain streams are renowned for their large populations of trout, especially the rainbow and brown.

headline: With Guardians, Cleveland Steps Away From an Offensive Name
text: Philip Yenyo has been protesting outside Cleveland’s baseball stadiums for 30 years, demanding the local Major League Baseball team change a name many consider racist. But next spring, Yenyo will put down his signs and take his 11-year-old son inside Progressive Field for the first time.

headline: Where Covid-19 Hospitalizations Are Rising in the U.S.
text: Covid-19 hospitalizations are trending upward in 45 states. While levels remain well below previous peaks, health care centers in parts of the Midwest, West and South are strained.

headline: Kanye West Unveils ‘Donda’ Album, With a Verse From Jay-Z
text: ATLANTA — A man who is rarely short on words, Kanye West didn’t even have a microphone.

headline: Astronomers See Moons Forming in Disk Around Distant Exoplanet
text: Our solar system is home to a magnificent menagerie of moons, from icy ones filled with turbulent oceans to volcanic ones decorated with pits of raging hellfire. To date, astronomers have discovered 4,438 worlds orbiting other stars, and there is no doubt that diverse moons dance around most of these exoplanets. But stargazers have yet to conclusively find any — these exomoons have proven too small and too far-flung to be spotted.

headline: Naomi Osaka lights the cauldron.
text: The torch relay ended with the tennis star Naomi Osaka lighting the Olympic cauldron in what is generally one of the most memorable parts of the opening ceremony.

headline: Tokyo Olympics Open to a Sea of Empty Seats
text: TOKYO — The athletes marched into the arena masked and waving exuberantly. Dancers in pastel costumes and hats clapped and moved their arms in the air to whip up excitement. But there were no fans and no cheering audience — only row upon row of mostly empty seats stretching into the reaches of the vast Olympic Stadium in central Tokyo.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. “I don’t question that the greatest meal salad of all time, the chef salad, was created by a chef,” Gabrielle Hamilton wrote for The New York Times Magazine this week. “The combination of textures and flavors is consummately professional. Sometimes people mistake the salad bowl for a lawless place of disorganized and mismatched ingredients, chopped up and thrown in — dried cranberries on top of pumpkin seeds on top of soggy corn — which offends even me, who stakes no strong claim to her chef bona fides. A salad nonetheless requires a bit of cheffing, a little experienced attention paid to balance, texture and restraint. Not everything tastes better with bacon bits scattered on top.”

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
text: Each month, we’re recommending five recent horror movies available to stream. Find more genre suggestions and other ways to navigate the streaming services at What to Watch.

headline: Did You See What the Liberian Olympic Team Is Wearing?
text: You might have missed it, but look again. They want to change the Olympic fashion game.

headline: Some Florida Hospitals Have More Covid Patients Than Ever Before
text: MIAMI — A month ago, the number of Covid-19 patients admitted at two University of Florida hospitals in Jacksonville was down to 14. Now more than 140 people are hospitalized with the coronavirus, a tenfold increase over five weeks — and the highest number of Covid-19 patients this system has seen during the pandemic.

headline: How to Calm Your Climate Anxiety
text: Three years ago, after the Woolsey Fire, 53-year-old Greg Kochanowski returned to the Santa Monica Mountains and drove past his own street without recognizing it.

headline: Vladimir Menshov, Surprise Russian Oscar Winner, Dies at 81
text: Vladimir Menshov, a prolific Soviet actor and director whose film “Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears” won the Academy Award in 1980 for best foreign-language film, surprising the many American critics who had panned it, died on July 5 in a hospital in Moscow. He was 81.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
text: The late-night hosts had no shortage of topics to riff on this week including the Summer Olympics and Jeff Bezos’s trip to space.

headline: Three-on-Three Basketball at the Olympics: What to Watch For
text: Eighty-five years after basketball’s debut in the Olympics, at the 1936 Berlin Games, a twist on the sport makes its Olympic debut in Tokyo. Three-on-three basketball, or 3x3 as the sport’s world governing body refers to it, promises a faster version than the traditional form.

headline: Even the Sheet Cakes Are Bigger in Texas
text: When Michelle Lopez immigrated to Houston from Manila as a teenager, her family’s new neighbors all dropped off the same welcome dessert: Texas sheet cake.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: A New Foil for Ted
text: So here we are. Relegation.

headline: Are Fitness Buffs Going Back to the Gym?
text: The 5:30 a.m. alarm to hit the spin class. The interminable waits for the ab-crunch machine. The masses of sweating bodies huffing and puffing just feet away, followed by the hurried shower and the wet-haired hustle to the office before the boss arrives.

headline: It’s a Grizzly Bear Survival Program. For Grizzly Bears.
text: One morning in mid-July, Lana M. Ciarniello, a bear biologist in British Columbia, caught a flight from Vancouver Island, where she lives, to a wildlife sanctuary in the northwestern part of the province to meet two baby grizzlies, the newest subjects in an unusual study she is conducting.

headline: Lil Nas X and Jack Harlow’s Prison Break, and 13 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Wonking Out: What Inflation Risks and My Intermittent Fasting Have in Common
text: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

headline: Biden hits the campaign trail for the first time as president, backing Terry McAuliffe for Virginia governor.
text: President Biden made a gleeful return to the campaign trail on Friday evening, joining former Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia, who is seeking to regain his old job in November, for his first campaign event since his inauguration.

headline: Make a Splash: 8 Summer Picture Books Take You to the Water
text: CHOICESWritten and illustrated by Roozeboos

headline: Arturo Schwarz, Refugee Who Became a Surrealism Tycoon, Dies at 97
text: Growing up in the 1930s and ’40s in the cosmopolitan port city of Alexandria, Egypt, Arturo Schwarz idolized European intellectuals.

headline: How to Make Brown-Butter Buffalo Sauce
text: Eric Kim, a writer for New York Times Cooking, demonstrates his recipe.

headline: Suspect Tries to Compare Capitol Riot to Last Year’s Violence in Portland, Ore.
text: The comparison has become a staple among right-wing figures in the news media and Republican politicians: The attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6 was really no different than the unrest last year that accompanied months of racial justice protests. Any discussion of the first should — out of fairness, they have said — make reference to the second.

headline: Naomi Osaka lights the Olympic cauldron to cap the opening ceremony.
text: TOKYO — An Olympic opening ceremony with all the usual pomp and tradition played out Friday night in Tokyo in front of a nearly empty stadium.

headline: Ugandan weight lifter who went missing in Japan returns home.
text: A weight lifter who went missing in Japan this month as he sought to qualify for the Tokyo Olympics has returned to Uganda and will be interrogated by police, authorities said on Friday — a week after his disappearance prompted international news headlines and drew mixed reactions from around the country.

headline: We Need a New Term for Video Games
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jerusalem Demsas
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jerusalem Demsas. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: N.Y.C.’s mayor calls for companies to require shots, as national debate over vaccine mandates picks up.
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio urged on Friday that New York City’s private businesses require their workers to get vaccinated against the coronavirus and signaled that he would introduce similar measures for hundreds of thousands of municipal employees.

headline: Amazon will investigate gender bias claims in its cloud division.
text: Amazon has hired a law firm to investigate claims of widespread gender discrimination in part of its cloud computing division, the company said in an email to employees late last week.

headline: Monsoon Season Drenches American Southwest
text: The heavy rain provided relief to parts of the region that have been battling drought. However, the storms came with life-threatening flash floods and lightning in places like Scottsdale, Ariz.
