text: SEOUL — South Korea’s female archers have been a dominant force, winning every women’s team competition since the event was first introduced at the 1988 Seoul Games.

headline: Novak Djokovic loses in a men’s singles tennis semifinal.
text: Novak Djokovic’s dream of a Golden Slam is over.

headline: The Delta variant is a ‘serious threat’ as contagious as chickenpox, the C.D.C. finds.
text: The Delta variant is much more contagious, more likely to break through protections afforded by the vaccines and may cause more severe disease than all other known versions of the virus, according to an internal presentation circulated within the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: How Europe, after a fumbling start, overtook the U.S. in vaccinations.
text: Fear and recrimination shook European capitals, while Washington brimmed with confidence. In early April, the European Union lagged far behind the United States in Covid-19 vaccination, the gap was widening rapidly, and the World Health Organization berated Europe for an “unacceptably slow” pace.

headline: A Treasure Trove Collected by Gloria Vanderbilt
text: Her Beekman Place two-bedroom is listed for $1.125 million

headline: The Story of Simone Biles
text: This episode contains mentions of sexual abuse.

headline: Gloria Vanderbilt’s Beekman Place Apartment Is for Sale
text: When Gloria Vanderbilt was 91, she and her son Anderson Cooper wrote a book together called “The Rainbow Comes and Goes.” It was an epistolary memoir, conducted by email, in which Mr. Cooper asked his mother all the questions he hoped never to be left with after her death: her true feelings about her storied, often tragic life, with its unimaginable losses — her own father’s death when she was a baby; his brother Carter’s suicide at 23; his father Wyatt Cooper’s death at 50 (when Anderson was 10 and Carter 12) — and unlikely high points (as when Ms. Vanderbilt made a fortune in the 1970s by putting her name on a pair of jeans, and in so doing changed the fashion business forever, only to lose it to a scheming lawyer in cahoots with her own psychiatrist).

headline: More Covid Mysteries
text: Consider these Covid-19 mysteries:

headline: In BMX Racing, Danger Is Never Far From the Lead
text: TOKYO — Perhaps it was an ominous sign, or maybe just a normal one, when BMX racing at the Olympics began Monday with a training run collision between a top cyclist and a marshal who wandered onto the track.

headline: Los Angeles schools order weekly virus tests for everyone, vaccinated or not.
text: The Los Angeles Unified School District announced on Thursday that it would require all students and employees returning for in-person instruction to participate in weekly coronavirus testing.

headline: He Hired 2 Men to Kidnap His Wife. They Ended Up Drowning.
text: Schanda Handley was at home with her daughter and a neighbor when two men showed up at the door, dressed in what looked like blue uniforms from an appliance store.

headline: Sarah Niles Needed ‘Ted Lasso,’ Too
text: The British actress Sarah Niles was, like many of us, a late convert to “Ted Lasso.” She missed the debut season when it rolled out on Apple TV+ last year, not getting her first taste until her agent sent her outtakes regarding a possible role in Season 2.

headline: SPACs on Trial
text: Trevor Milton, the founder of Nikola, is one of the most high-profile figures at the center of the boom in SPAC deals. Yesterday he was hit with criminal and civil charges by the U.S. attorney’s office in Manhattan and the S.E.C. The prosecutors accuse Milton of misleading investors about the technology for the company’s battery- and hydrogen-powered vehicles. Nikola went public in June last year by merging with a blank-check firm, VectorIQ, founded by a former G.M. executive.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 8: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
text: Welcome to Week Eight of our 12th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: The Fed’s Favorite Price Index Rose 4 Percent. What Comes Next?
text: The Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of inflation climbed by 4 percent in June compared with a year earlier, as a rebounding economy and strong demand for goods and services helped to push prices higher.

headline: One of the Teams Dominating the Olympics: California
text: Good morning.

headline: Nonprofits Get a New Type of Donation: Cryptocurrency
text: The University of Pennsylvania recently announced a $5 million gift to Wharton, its business school. The donation was not one of its largest, but the university announced the gift with the type of fanfare it usually lavishes on gifts many times its size.

headline: Remains of Esther Dingley, Missing British Hiker, Are Found
text: The remains of Esther Dingley, a British woman who went missing while hiking alone in the Pyrenees mountains eight months ago, have been found, according to an international support group for missing person cases.

headline: Sharks Are Spotted Off Long Island. Scientists Say Don’t Panic.
text: Police helicopters scanning the waves for dorsal fins. Bathers pacing on beaches, waiting for the all-clear to go back in the water. A mysterious bite on a lifeguard’s leg.

headline: They Spurned the Vaccine. Now They Want You to Know They Regret It.
text: PROVO, Utah — As Mindy Greene spent another day in the Covid intensive care unit, listening to the whirring machines that now breathed for her 42-year-old husband, Russ, she opened her phone and tapped out a message.

headline: The U.S., trusting its goalkeeper to save the day, beats the Netherlands to reach the Olympic semifinals.
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan — It was only afterward that Alyssa Naeher let down her guard. After she had dived to saved the penalty kick late in the game. After she had dived again to push aside the header in extra time. After she had turned away not one but two penalties in the shootout.

headline: How Black Foragers Find Freedom in the Natural World
text: When Alexis Nikole Nelson was a kindergartner, she counted a honeysuckle tree among her most cherished friends.

headline: Israeli Officials Say Iran Is Behind Deadly Attack on Oil Tanker
text: JERUSALEM — An oil tanker managed by an Israeli-owned shipping firm was attacked on Thursday night off the coast of Oman, killing two crew members, according to the firm and three Israeli officials.

headline: In ‘Mr. Corman,’ Joseph Gordon-Levitt Looks Inward and Asks, ‘What If?’
text: Joseph Gordon-Levitt is the first to admit he’s had it pretty good. He has had a wildly successful acting career on stages and screens spanning over three decades. He sings, dances, writes and directs, and he does a decent Nirvana cover. He has a wife and two kids and he hardly seems to age.

headline: Broadway Audiences Will Need Proof of Vaccination and Masks
text: Broadway’s theater owners and operators, citing the ongoing dangers of the coronavirus pandemic, said Friday that they have decided to require that theatergoers be vaccinated against Covid-19 and wear masks in order to attend performances.

headline: The Tao of Snoop Dogg
text: Nearly 30 years after emerging as a profane gangster rapper from Long Beach, Calif., Snoop Dogg has transcended his hip-hop roots and become culturally ubiquitous.

headline: Turkey Is Next as Wildfires Afflict Mediterranean Countries
text: Firefighters in Turkey struggled to contain dozens of wildfires raging for a fourth day on Saturday, as fast-spreading blazes forced popular holiday resorts and dozens of rural areas along the Mediterranean coast to be evacuated.

headline: Bootleg Fire Victim Tours Remains of Burned Home
text: The Bootleg Fire, which has burned hundreds of thousands of acres in southern Oregon, is the nation’s largest active blaze. Marc Valens showed us how the fire destroyed his home.

headline: Take a Tour of the Olympic Village
text: India Pagán, who plays center for the women’s basketball team from Puerto Rico, walked us through her day in Tokyo.

headline: Novak Djokovic, King of the Olympic Village, Loses Run at Golden Slam
text: TOKYO — Novak Djokovic’s dream of a Golden Slam ended in the early hours of another thick night at the Olympics, on one last searing winner off the racket of Germany’s Alexander Zverev.

headline: Olympic Success Gives Hong Kong an Emotional Lift in Hard Times
text: TOKYO — The light red flag with the five-petaled bauhinia flower does not represent a country. But Hong Kong, the Chinese territory where political and civil rights have been battered in recent months, is enjoying its strongest-ever showing at the Tokyo Olympics, capturing gold in fencing and two silvers in swimming.

headline: Sunisa Lee’s Next Big Move After the Olympics: College
text: TOKYO — The thing Sunisa Lee is most looking forward to now that she is the Olympic all-around gymnastics champion is not her instant fame as one of Team U.S.A.’s biggest stars. It’s packing up her belongings less than a week after she arrives home in Minnesota from the Tokyo Games so she can head to college.

headline: Georginio Wijnaldum and the Collective Toxic
text: This is not a comparison, because there is no comparison. Nobody, really, can understand what it is like to be Simone Biles. There have, of course, been athletes burdened with the same sort of level of superhuman expectation, their personhood erased in the transcendence to icon, turned into the face of a sport or an avatar for a generation or a standard-bearer for a nation, but they number barely a handful.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. Tejal Rao’s working her box grater hard these days, as tomatoes ripen in her backyard in Los Angeles, sit sun-kissed on tables at the farmer’s market or tumble off piles at the store. “At the grater,” she wrote for The New York Times Magazine this week, “every tomato is the same: I make it a game to not waste a single bit of meat, to push my palm right against the metal and get down to a fine, translucent skin that curls at the edges.”

headline: Stream These Five International Films Now
text: In the age of streaming, the earth is flat — screen-size, with travel to faraway destinations only a monthly subscription and a click away. We’ve journeyed through the world of options and chosen the best new international movies for you to watch.

headline: Tokyo Olympics on Friday: U.S. Women’s Soccer to Semifinals
text: The Americans beat the Netherlands in a shootout. They play Canada next.

headline: A death in Kentucky is at least the fifth in the U.S. this month from flash flooding.
text: A woman in Kentucky was killed in flash flooding during heavy rain overnight that left about 10 people trapped in their homes and sent cars floating down streets, an official said.

headline: Walmart and Disney Join a Growing Group of Businesses Requiring Vaccines
text: Employers held off for months on making decisions about vaccine mandates, worried about the legal and political fallout. But facing renewed pandemic restrictions, and with encouragement from government leaders, a growing number of the country’s biggest companies have been embracing the idea.

headline: Trump Pressed Justice Dept. to Declare Election Results Corrupt, Notes Show
text: WASHINGTON — President Donald J. Trump pressed top Justice Department officials late last year to declare that the election was corrupt even though they had found no instances of widespread fraud, so he and his allies in Congress could use the assertion to try to overturn the results, according to new documents provided to lawmakers.

headline: Some in Missouri Seek Covid-19 Shots in Secret, Doctor Says
text: Even as the more contagious Delta variant drives a surge in infections, the Covid-19 vaccination effort has become so polarized in Missouri that some people are trying to get shots in secret to avoid conflicts with friends and relatives, a doctor there said.

headline: How Disabled Americans Are Pushing to Overhaul a Key Benefits Program
text: When Congress created Supplemental Security Income in 1972, it left no question about its intentions. The program, lawmakers wrote, was “designed to provide a positive assurance that the nation’s aged, blind and disabled people would no longer have to subsist on below-poverty-level incomes.”

headline: The Weekender
text: Meet the gardening columnist who ended up documenting climate change. Also in this edition: the unappreciated importance of cats.

headline: U.S. restaurants scramble to reimpose rules.
text: As the Delta variant of the coronavirus has become the most predominant variant in the United States and medical experts issue confusing advice, restaurateurs find themselves once again making difficult decisions. Where laws allow, many have begun requiring patrons to bring proof of vaccination before dining.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ta-Nehisi Coates and Nikole Hannah-Jones
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ta-Nehisi Coates and Nikole Hannah-Jones. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: It’s OK to Say No to More Work
text: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Legends Remade: New Science Fiction and Fantasy
text: Marissa Levien’s THE WORLD GIVES WAY (Redhook, 402 pp., $28) is a staggering marvel, an action-packed cat-and-mouse chase on a doomed generation ship the size of Switzerland. Myrra Dal is a contract worker, one of thousands of people serving out indentures signed by their great-grandparents in exchange for passage off a dying Earth. To her, and to most of the other citizens descended from those first passengers, the ship is the world: It has a sky, cities, weather, climates, a desert and a sea. It also has a crack in its hull — widening, irreparable and kept secret by its wealthiest families — and 50 years remaining in its 200-year voyage.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: The Return of Jamie Tartt
text: Jamie Tartt, doo doo da doo da doo, Jamie Tartt, doo doo da doo da doo.

headline: Greece Accuses Aid Groups of Helping Smugglers of Migrants
text: ATHENS — As Greece faces criticism for its quick return of migrants across the Aegean Sea to Turkey, it is cracking down on the activities of some aid groups working with refugees, accusing them of facilitating trafficking rackets and spying.

headline: N.Y.C.’s mayor says mask guidance will come on Monday, but remains focused on greater vaccination.
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Friday that the city would “delineate to New Yorkers the best way to use masks” on Monday, but held firm to the idea that vaccinations against the coronavirus is the best way to fight the pandemic.

headline: In the Rio Grande Valley, for a Different Kind of Football Story
text: Late on the evening of Dec. 3, news broke that a high school football player from the Rio Grande Valley of Texas had rushed and leveled a referee after being ejected from a game. Video of the vicious hit spread rapidly, and the player was jailed and charged with misdemeanor assault. Social media responded with fury, condemnation and threats.

headline: ‘The Green Knight’ | Anatomy of a Scene
text: David Lowery narrates a sequence from “The Green Knight” featuring Dev Patel and Erin Kellyman.

headline: Take a Journey With Dev Patel in ‘The Green Knight’
text: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Western Governors Seek Federal Aid in Wildfire Battle
text: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California and Gov. Steve Sisolak of Nevada called for more federal firefighting assistance, as the states experienced yet another catastrophic wildfire season.

headline: Credit to Tech’s Pandemic Leadership
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it three times a week.

headline: Oklahoma and Texas to Join SEC and Add to a Juggernaut
text: The University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas on Friday defied the Big 12’s fury and agreed to defect to the Southeastern Conference, college football’s mightiest league and a juggernaut with few equals in American sports.

headline: Spanish Court Targets Chilean Bank Tied to Pinochet
text: MADRID — Nearly 15 years after the death of the former Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet, victims of his brutal regime are still trying to hold him and his associates accountable. And now the victims appear to be one step closer to justice — even if the courtroom is on the other side of the world.

headline: Silk Sonic’s Retro Roller Jam, and 12 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Ruth Pearl, Mother of Murdered Reporter Daniel Pearl, Dies at 85
text: Ruth Pearl, the mother of Daniel Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was brutally murdered by Muslim extremists in Pakistan in 2002, thrusting her and her husband, Judea, into the global spotlight, died on July 20 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 85.

headline: Severe Thunderstorms Sweep Across Wisconsin
text: The strong storms hit parts of Wisconsin and elsewhere in the Midwest this week, causing widespread damage and heavy rainfall.

headline: My Sister Remembers Her Past Life. Somehow, I Believe Her.
text: When we were younger, my older sister Heba kept a photo on her dresser in our bedroom that always caught my eye. She said I was the young red-haired girl in the picture, but I was born with blonde curls and had light brown hair at the time. The girl in the picture was named Sara, like me, and I would later learn that the full story of the photo was too baffling for me to understand at the time.

headline: Vaccinated People May Spread the Virus, Though Rarely, C.D.C. Reports
text: In yet another unexpected and unwelcome twist in the pandemic, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released on Friday a report strongly suggesting that fully immunized people with so-called breakthrough infections of the Delta variant can spread the virus to others just as readily as unvaccinated people.

headline: Overlooked No More: Janet Sobel, Whose Art Influenced Jackson Pollock
text: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Here’s who is hospitalized for Covid in New York City.
text: Since early July, the average number of coronavirus cases in New York City has quadrupled, from about 250 to more than 1,000 per day, as the more contagious variant Delta has spread.

headline: L Brands Agrees to New Policies Tied to Sexual Harassment Claims
text: L Brands, the owner of Victoria’s Secret and Bath & Body Works, will release current and former employees from nondisclosure agreements tied to sexual harassment claims and take steps to to promote diversity, equity and inclusion as part of a settlement with shareholders announced on Friday.

headline: This Shrimp Recipe Will Bring You Joy
text: I was inspired by something I saw on Twitter this week (I know, strange): The podcast host and author Linda Holmes wrote that, after a pandemic stretch of ordering in and PB&Js, she wanted to reset her relationship with her kitchen. She issued herself a cooking challenge, choosing eight New York Times Cooking recipes and making them over the course of one week. (Among the recipes: this arugula salad with peaches and goat cheese; these chile-oil noodles; and our ginger-lime chicken.)

headline: Inside a Covid I.C.U., Hopes Fade as Patients Surge In
text: MIAMI — Alix Zacharski, a nurse manager, went to check on one of her patients inside the Covid-19 intensive care unit at Miami’s Jackson Memorial Hospital on a recent afternoon, hoping that the patient, who had been struggling to breathe on her own, would be a little better. But these days inside the Covid I.C.U., almost everything is worse.

headline: Democrats scramble to save the federal eviction freeze, as frustration with Biden mounts.
text: House Democrats scrambled on Friday to scrape up the votes needed to extend the federal eviction moratorium through the end of the year — a long shot bid to keep the freeze from expiring on Saturday — as leaders vented frustration with President Biden for punting the issue to them.

headline: The Pleasure of Falling Asleep With a Book on Your Face
text: Maybe you should just surrender to the sweet slumber.

headline: The U.S. will cover cost of testing unvaccinated federal workers.
text: The U.S. government will cover the costs of regular coronavirus testing for unvaccinated federal workers, one component of the Biden administration’s new vaccination requirements.

headline: Repression, Obsession, Murder
text: It’s unlikely that an art teacher as hot and louche as Mr. Lavelle could ever get a job at Temple House, an all-girls’ Irish Catholic boarding school run mostly by nuns. But there he is in all his sexual-innuendo-laden glory, bringing frissons of inappropriate excitement to the supposedly virginal students in Rachel Donohue’s steamily atmospheric debut, THE TEMPLE HOUSE VANISHING (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, 304 pp., paper, $16.95). “My role is not to teach,” he declares pretentiously. “You rather must show me, tell me who you are through your work.”

headline: Wonking Out: Keynesian Republicans, Supply-Side Democrats?
text: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

headline: New York City Awards $3 Million for Latino and Puerto Rican Theater
text: The New York City Department of Cultural Affairs announced on Friday that the city had awarded $3 million to Pregones/Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, which champions Puerto Rican and Latino artists and produces original bilingual plays and musicals.

headline: Poetry and Politics, HIPAA and Other Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Treasury must turn over Trump’s taxes to Congress, the Justice Dept. says.
text: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department must turn over six years of former President Donald J. Trump’s tax returns to House investigators, the Justice Department said in a legal opinion issued on Friday that most likely paves the way for their eventual release to Congress and potentially to the public.

headline: ‘The Jetpack Guy Is Back’: Los Angeles Sighting Draws an Inquiry, Again
text: A pilot flying a Boeing 747 on Wednesday night looked toward the right wing of the plane and reported a strange figure zooming over Los Angeles.

headline: This Vegetarian Menu Brings Home the Best of the Market
text: This time of year, my diet turns almost completely plant-based.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Antkind’ and ‘Looking for Miss America’
text: BEGIN AGAIN: James Baldwin’s America and Its Urgent Lessons for Our Own, by Eddie S. Glaude Jr. (Crown, 288 pp., $17.) Glaude, an African American studies professor at Princeton, didn’t believe white America would ever elect “such a person” as Trump president. “I was wrong, and given my lifelong reading of Baldwin, it was an egregious mistake.” In his latest book, the author of “Democracy in Black” searches Baldwin’s work for answers to “how an insidious view of race … continues to frustrate any effort to ‘achieve our country.’”

headline: Devastation Grips California as Dixie Fire Burns
text: The Dixie Fire continued to burn through Northern California at an alarming rate as firefighters struggled to contain the strong blaze amid record-breaking temperatures.

headline: What Should I Do With My White Privilege at Work?
text: I am a white woman who was recently promoted to a high-level administrative position in my school district. At the same time, highly experienced and qualified Black women were displaced from their leadership positions. While the school district is requiring all employees to address issues of race and equity, our hiring practices do not reflect these values. I am challenged by my decision to continue to hold my leadership role and my position in the midst of these conflicting messages, actions and values. What can I do to address these inconsistencies and this discrimination?I’m sure you’re feeling guilty about how you may have unfairly benefited from your employer’s actions. But the district (including all the kids who go to school there) is better off with you in a leadership role than it would be with someone who didn’t care about discrimination. And your leaving, obviously, won’t make the district hire or promote more Black women. So I don’t want you to quit this job.

headline: Guggenheim Museum Curators Move to Join a Union
text: For decades there were no unions at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, but now its curators, conservators, editors and other employees are aiming to form the second in just over two years, organizing with a local connected to the United Auto Workers.

headline: Lakers’ Russell Westbrook Deal Shifts Power Back to Los Angeles
text: As the N.B.A. braces for the start of free agency negotiations on Monday, a pending blockbuster trade that would send Russell Westbrook to the Los Angeles Lakers is already in the running to be this summer’s most impactful transaction.

headline: Biden’s Renewed Drive Against Covid
text: To the Editor:

headline: From ‘Call My Agent!’ to Hollywood Career
text: At some point during the pandemic, perhaps between the debut of “Ted Lasso” last August and “Bridgerton” in December, you may have happened upon Netflix’s French import “Call My Agent!” (“Dix Pour Cent” in French), a sweet yet absurd sendup of the global entertainment complex as seen through the lens of a Parisian talent agency where the agents are mostly good-hearted lovers of cinema at the beck and call of their highly demanding clients.

headline: Florida’s governor gives parents final say on masks for children in school.
text: Defiant in the face of new federal mask recommendations, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Friday signed an executive order directing state officials to ensure that parents have the power to decide for themselves whether their children wear masks in school this fall.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Welcome. August begins on Sunday, a new month, a good time to set an intention for the coming weeks. There’s so much that’s uncertain, that we can’t figure out or control right now. Doing what we can to add some predictability or structure to the days can help things feel a little more coherent.

headline: House Democrats Call for C.D.C. to Expand Eviction Moratorium
text: Lawmakers were racing on Friday to extend the federal eviction moratorium through the end of the year, as it’s set to expire on Saturday, and was responsible for slowing the pace of evictions during the pandemic.

headline: The Yips, the Twisties, the Waggles: Simone Biles Gets Them, and You Probably Do Too
text: There is a regrettable incident involving a dog, a pigeon and a free kick. A soccer player loses his mojo. His coaches try to name the problem.

headline: Those Virus Sequences That Were Suddenly Deleted? They’re Back
text: A batch of early coronavirus data that went missing for a year has emerged from hiding.

headline: Echoes of a Fairy Tale in a Devastating Novel
text: Omar El Akkad’s new novel, “What Strange Paradise,” uses some fablelike techniques to comment on the migrant crisis caused by war in the Middle East. El Akkad explains that he thinks of the novel as a reinterpretation of the story of Peter Pan, told as the story of a contemporary child refugee.

headline: Climate Chaos Is Avoidable. Here’s How.
text: You might have read some dismal headlines this week: On Tuesday, enough ice melted in Greenland to cover Florida in two inches of water, fires are engulfing Northern California and parts of the Mediterranean, and Europe is still flooding.

headline: Infrastructure Deal Puts Cryptocurrencies in Washington’s Cross Hairs
text: WASHINGTON — In a hunt for funds to help pay for the Senate’s bipartisan infrastructure package, lawmakers have turned to the cryptocurrency industry as a potential source of tax revenue and are proposing tougher scrutiny of digital transactions.

headline: The New Reality of a European Trip: ‘Things Are Going to Change’
text: When Europe reopened its borders to Americans in mid-June, it seemed to promise a summer of relative normality, with U.S. tourists boarding trans-Atlantic flights and once again freely strolling the plazas of the continent’s cities.

headline: Virus cases are rising around the world, and deaths in Africa are surging.
text: Confirmed coronavirus infections have jumped in much of the world, and deaths from the disease in Africa have increased by 80 percent over the last four weeks, the director-general of the World Health Organization said on Friday.

headline: Murder Trial in Sweden Could Shine Unsavory Light on Iran’s New President
text: He was a 28-year-old student and member of a communist group in Iran serving a 10-year prison sentence in 1988 when, according to his family, he was called before a committee and executed without a trial or defense.

headline: 5 Songs to Listen to Right Now
text: Here are five new and notable songs, including Lil Nas X and Jack Harlow’s prison break and Camila Cabello’s exuberant new single.

headline: N.C.A.A. Looks to Rewrite Its Constitution and Stave Off Critics
text: The N.C.A.A., with its authority curbed by the Supreme Court, its conferences jostling for influence and its future deeply uncertain, said Friday that it would look to rewrite its constitution.

headline: Bezos’ Rocket Company Loses Challenge to NASA SpaceX Moon Contract
text: Jeff Bezos’ rocket company carried him to the edge of space last week. But it won’t be flying NASA astronauts to the moon’s surface, at least for now.

headline: Tornadoes Tear Through Ohio, Pennsylvania and New Jersey
text: Several people were injured after tornadoes were reported throughout the Mid-Atlantic region. The storms left behind a trail of damaged buildings and power outages.

headline: Chuck E. Weiss, Musician Who, in Love, Inspired a Hit Song, Dies at 76
text: Chuck E. Weiss, blues musician, club owner and outsize Los Angeles character who was immortalized in Rickie Lee Jones’s breakout hit song, “Chuck E.’s in Love,” died on July 20 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 76.

headline: Wildfires Rage Across Turkey
text: Turkey struggled to contain the dozens of wildfires burning this week, as local residents and tourists along the Mediterranean Coast were forced to evacuate.

headline: Needing Some Extra Magic, the Mets Trade for El Mago
text: The Mets arrived at Friday’s trade deadline with an offense that averaged just 3.85 runs per game. Only two teams were worse: the Texas Rangers and the Pittsburgh Pirates, and both of them are in last place in their divisions.

headline: Three Members of the Olympic Refugee Team Will Soon Call Canada Home
text: At this year’s Olympics, Team Canada is 371 athletes-strong, the country’s largest team to compete since the 1984 Games in Los Angeles.

headline: Timothy Rub Will Step Down at Philadelphia Museum of Art
text: Timothy Rub, 69, the director and chief executive officer of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, on Friday announced that he will retire early in 2022, after 13 years at the helm of one of the most prestigious art museums in the country.

headline: U.S. Authorities Seek Documents From Troubled Covid Vaccine Manufacturer
text: Troubles continued to mount on Friday for a Maryland vaccine manufacturer as it disclosed publicly for the first time that federal and state law enforcement and regulatory agencies were seeking information from the company.

headline: Delta, Trump, Haiti: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Delta Variant Forces Japan to Extend State of Emergency
text: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan announced that the government would expand a state of emergency to other areas besides Tokyo, and that the restrictions in the capital would be extended until the end of August after the Olympics concludes.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: The past year and a half has been one of the most turbulent periods in recent real estate history. The pandemic not only changed where some of us lived, but also what home means.

headline: U.S. women’s soccer advances to the semifinals, and other highlights from Friday.
text: TOKYO — The U.S. women’s soccer team defeated the Netherlands on penalties after a 2-2 draw in their quarterfinal on Friday night. Next up, a semifinal against Canada on Monday.

headline: Ryan Murphy casts doubt on whether a Russian swimmer beat him cleanly.
text: Ryan Murphy won a silver medal for the United States in the men’s 200-meter backstroke and then caused some fireworks in his news conference when he questioned whether his race, won by a Russian, was drug free, given Russia’s history of doping in sports.

headline: The women’s 100-meter dash is ahead.
text: TOKYO — Track and field is fully underway at the Tokyo Olympics, and the race to be the fastest woman in the world is Saturday’s biggest highlight. The women’s 100 meters is set for 9:50 p.m. Tokyo time, 8:50 a.m. Eastern.

headline: Zach Wilson’s Arrival Is Just Enough to Stoke Jets’ Dreams
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As Zach Wilson flew on a red-eye flight from California to the East Coast early Thursday morning, he reclined in one of those premier seats that converts into a bed. He got plenty of sleep, he said.

headline: Justice Dept. sues Texas governor over an executive order on migrants.
text: The Justice Department sued Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Friday in an effort to block an executive order that severely limits the transportation of migrants in the state, calling the order unconstitutional.

headline: Roberto Calasso, Renaissance Man of Letters, Dies at 80
text: Roberto Calasso, the Italian publisher, translator and writer whose wide-ranging works explored the evolution and mysteries of human consciousness, from the earliest myths and rituals to modern civilization, died on Wednesday in Milan. He was 80.

headline: Short of the Mandate They Crave, Military Leaders Race to Vaccinate Troops
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — Three soldiers in camouflage were crowded around a table at a popular burrito place near Fort Carson on Friday, chewing over the announcement that the military might soon require all troops to get vaccinated for coronavirus. Two of the soldiers had already gotten the shot. One had not.

headline: My Country Has Been a Dictatorship Before. We Can’t Go Back.
text: On the morning of July 26, my colleagues and I — all of us democratically elected members of Parliament — found the Parliament building in downtown Tunis surrounded by army tanks and our access blocked on the orders of President Kais Saied.

headline: Some New Yorkers say $100 offer inspired them to get vaccinated.
text: Robert Byng was determined to receive his first shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine at the Bushwick branch of the Brooklyn Public Library on Friday, and said that he had pushed back an interview to be there.

headline: At a Wild Trade Deadline, Every Club Made a Move
text: It was easily the wildest, most frenetic trade deadline in major league history. Ten players who were All-Stars in mid-July were traded by Friday afternoon. Two recent champions, the Chicago Cubs and the Washington Nationals, scattered pieces of their souls across the baseball landscape. Every team made at least one deal this week, and 27 of the 30 made a move on Friday.

headline: How to watch today’s swimming.
text: More gold medals are up for grabs today, in the 100-meter men’s butterfly (Caelab Dressel of the U.S. is favored), the women’s 200-meter backstroke (two Americans were the top qualifiers), the women’s 800-meter freestyle (can Katie Ledecky of the U.S. claim another distance gold?) and the 4x100-meter mixed gender medley relay (first time for this even in the Olympics).

headline: Richard Lamm, Governor and Early Abortion Rights Supporter, Dies at 85
text: Richard D. Lamm, who as a Colorado state legislator led fights to pass the nation’s first abortion rights law in the years before Roe v. Wade and to block the 1976 Winter Olympics from being held in his state, and who went on to serve three terms as Colorado’s governor, died on Thursday in Denver. He was 85.

headline: ‘This Isn’t How We’re Supposed to Live’: Residents Flee as Dixie Fire Surges
text: QUINCY, Calif. — The knock on the door came at 3 in the afternoon, as smoke was filling the sky. When Kristina Bowen heard the Plumas County sheriff’s deputy shouting, she knew she had to move fast.

headline: U.S. broadcast coverage on Friday night includes several swimming events.
text: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Friday evening and overnight. All times are Eastern.

headline: Here’s a preview of swimming races today.
text: TOKYO — Swimming today (Saturday morning in Tokyo, Friday night in the U.S.) presents the second-to-last day of the competition, the last race for Katie Ledecky and another chance for Caeleb Dressel to win gold.

headline: An Unlikely Pair, Portman and Sinema Steer Infrastructure Deal
text: WASHINGTON — It had scarcely been 24 hours since a breakthrough vote in the Senate to move forward with a $1 trillion infrastructure bill when the two lead negotiators on the deal, Senators Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, and Kyrsten Sinema, Democrat of Arizona, knew they had a problem.

headline: Have a Question for Eric Adams?
text: Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, is almost certain to become the next mayor of New York City. He won the Democratic primary in a city where registered Democrats vastly outnumber Republicans.

headline: The Spectacle of Latinx Colorism
text: This summer’s controversy over the underrepresentation of dark-skinned Afro-Latinos in “In the Heights,” the Hollywood adaptation of the Broadway musical, laid bare the cancer of colorism in Latinx communities in the United States. The reckoning was long overdue, a pain that goes back as long as our community has existed. And the mainstream media was enraptured. It created what I think of as the spectacle — el espectáculo. I haven’t seen as high a demand for Latinx voices since the Pulse shooting.

headline: Simone Biles will not compete in the uneven bars or vault event finals.
text: Simone Biles, the superstar American gymnast, will not compete in Sunday’s event finals for vault and uneven bars at the Tokyo Games, according to U.S.A. Gymnastics. Earlier this week, she withdrew from the event finals and the all-around final, citing mental health reasons, and she is still eligible for finals in the floor exercise on Monday and the balance beam on Tuesday.

headline: Caeleb Dressel won the men’s 100-meter butterfly, setting a world record.
text: Caeleb Dressel of the United States won his third gold medal of these Olympics, setting a world record in the 100-meter butterfly with a time of 49.45 seconds.

headline: Kaylee McKeown of Australia won the 200-meter women’s backstroke.
text: Kaylee McKeown of Australia won the 200-meter women’s backstroke in a time of 2 minutes 4.68 seconds, defeating Kylie Masse of Canada and Emily Seebohm of Australia.

headline: Katie Ledecky won the women’s 800-meter freestyle.
text: TOKYO — Katie Ledecky concluded her Tokyo Olympics with another gold medal in an event she has dominated her entire career, the 800-meter freestyle.

headline: Accessible
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Wow! The top half of this grid is a tough nut to crack, which makes the “belt” at 32-Across exceptionally wry. Brian Thomas and Brooke Husic collaborated on another hard Saturday puzzle back in June; these are great puzzles for aficionados, because they pose challenge after challenge, but even if you feel trepidation about Saturdays you will find that a little risk-taking will push you over the top, a very satisfying feeling.

headline: Simone Manuel failed to qualify for the women’s 50 free final.
text: Simone Manuel of the United States failed to qualify for the 50-meter freestyle final after finishing 11th out of 16 swimmers in semifinal heats in a time of 24.63 seconds.

headline: Britain won the mixed medley relay, a new event.
text: TOKYO — Britain won the mixed medley relay in a time of 3 minutes 37.58, setting a world record in the first time the event was held at the Olympics. China took silver and Australia bronze, followed by Italy and the United States.

headline: Editors’ Note: July 31, 2021
text: An article on March 30 about Liberty University’s decision to reopen its campus after its spring break referred imprecisely to the university medical staff’s concerns about Covid-19 on campus. While several students reported to the campus health center with respiratory illnesses, the staff did not conclude that their symptoms indicated that there was a Covid-19 outbreak on campus. One student tested positive.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Grief and Fury After Surviving Night of Terror
text: “In my mind, everybody was dead, because if the president could die, everybody else could have died too.”

headline: A Nigerian sprinter is suspended after a failed drug test.
text: Track and field’s drug testing agency temporarily suspended a Nigerian sprinter after a failed drug test, the first drug-related suspension of an active athlete at the Tokyo Games.

headline: Katie Ledecky and Caeleb Dressel delivered yet again.
text: TOKYO — It was the Katie and Caeleb Show, an ongoing series at swimming, as the Americans continued their medal haul at the Olympics.

headline: Female Sprinters Take the Spotlight at Tokyo’s ‘Superfast’ Track
text: TOKYO — For years, the 100-meter dash was synonymous with one stupendously fast human: Usain Bolt, who won three straight Olympic titles before he retired in 2017. He has since occupied his time with dabbling in professional soccer, selling cars, traveling the world as a bon vivant and becoming a new father.

headline: N.F.L. Vaccine Holdouts Face Training Camp Scrutiny
text: When asked by reporters Tuesday if he had received the Covid-19 vaccine, Indianapolis Colts defensive lineman DeForest Buckner nodded his head and smiled.

headline: ‘It Feels Like We’re Just Waiting to Die’: Hong Kong Targets Student Unions
text: HONG KONG — The police arrived at the University of Hong Kong around 3 p.m., wearing black vests marking them as national security officers. They cordoned off the offices of the student union, combed its interior and seized several bins of material.

headline: Trump Raised $56 Million Online in First Half of 2021
text: Despite departing from office and being barred from the leading social media platforms, former President Donald J. Trump was the Republican Party’s most dominant fund-raiser in the early months of 2021, as committees affiliated with him collected more than $56 million online, according to campaign filings made late Friday.

headline: The U.S. broadcast on Saturday morning includes finals in women’s tennis and archery.
text: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Saturday morning. All times are Eastern.

headline: For Katie Ledecky, the Longer the Race the Better
text: How Katie Ledecky’s competitors are closing the gap on her dominance in the pool.

headline: Pablo Carreño Busta beat Novak Djokovic to win the bronze in men’s singles tennis.
text: TOKYO — Pablo Carreño Busta, a highly ranked Spaniard who has twice reached the semifinals of the U.S. Open but never broken through in a big way on the professional tour, outlasted Novak Djokovic, the top men’s player in the world, to win a bronze medal at the Tokyo Games on Saturday.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.

headline: We Asked Daves About Dave, Marcus and Other First-Name Money Apps
text: Dave and his bros are having a moment.

headline: Body of Reuters Photographer Was Mutilated in Taliban Custody, Officials Say
text: NEW DELHI — The body of Danish Siddiqui, a Pulitzer Prize-winning Reuters photojournalist who was killed in Afghanistan this month, was badly mutilated while in the custody of the Taliban, officials said this week.

headline: As Covid Cases Rise All Over U.S., Lower Vaccination Rates Point to Worse Outcomes
text: Counties with low vaccination rates continue to bear the brunt of the highly contagious Delta variant, and some are seeing their highest case rates of the entire pandemic.

headline: Cults, College Dropouts and the Art of Control in Two New Story Collections
text: WE WANT WHAT WE WANT Stories By Alix Ohlin

headline: You Anon
text: In early July, when England’s soccer team lost the European Championship final to Italy on its home turf, the crushing defeat was followed by a torrent of racist abuse on social media directed at the team’s Black players. The messages — part of an ongoing pattern of social media bigotry — were condemned by politicians, platforms, teammates and fans.

headline: Biden, Republicans and the Pandemic Blame Game
text: President Biden is in a tough spot: He campaigned on the ideas that he had the team to manage a pandemic and that his five-decade career as a Washington deal maker was just the ticket to overcome the country’s political polarization.

headline: Maitreyi Ramakrishnan of ‘Never Have I Ever’ Loves Van Gogh
text: Cobalt and ultramarine blue swirled on the floors and walls. A moon appeared. Then stars. And the tangled branches of cypress trees. “‘Starry Night,’” Maitreyi Ramakrishnan murmured on a sultry July morning. “This is like the headliner act.”

headline: Ta-Ta to ‘Teetering Tabloids’: Keith Kelly Signs Off
text: The happiest man in Midtown Manhattan last Monday morning might have been Keith J. Kelly, the longtime media columnist for The New York Post. It was the first day of his retirement and he was puffing on a Cohiba while perambulating down West 55th street.

headline: Accusations of Sexual Abuse Continue to Roil Basketball in Mali
text: The president of Mali’s basketball federation has been suspended and the West African nation’s former women’s youth national coach has been jailed on charges of sexually abusing players, according to the country’s sports ministry and the prosecutor in the assault case.

headline: No Pool? Here’s How to Make a Splash in the Yard Anyway.
text: With more than a month of summer left — one that’s shaping up to be among the hottest on record — a cool dip in the water is an ideal way to spend a blistering August afternoon. Even if you aren’t fortunate enough to have your own in-ground pool, you can still create a splash in your own backyard — you just have to get creative.

headline: This Is Our Chance to Pull Teenagers Out of the Smartphone Trap
text: As students return to school in the coming weeks, there will be close attention to their mental health. Many problems will be attributed to the Covid pandemic, but in fact we need to look back further, to 2012.

headline: New Rule Raises Question: Who’ll Pay for All the Covid Tests?
text: Spurred by rising Covid cases and the Delta variant’s spread, a wave of major employers announced the same rule for unvaccinated workers this week: They will need to submit to regular surveillance testing. The new requirement raises a thorny question: Who pays for those coronavirus tests?

headline: A Plant That ‘Cannot Die’ Reveals Its Genetic Secrets
text: The longest-lived leaves in the plant kingdom can be found only in the harsh, hyperarid desert that crosses the boundary between southern Angola and northern Namibia.

headline: Home Prices Are Soaring. Is That the Fed’s Problem?
text: Robert S. Kaplan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, has been nervously eyeing the housing market as he ponders the path ahead for monetary policy. Home prices are rising at a double-digit pace this year. The typical house in and around the city he calls home sold for $306,031 in June of this year, Zillow estimates, up from $261,710 a year earlier.

headline: A Brief History of Summer Reading
text: When the days get longer and the mercury begins to rise, the books appear. Sunscreen-dappled paperbacks are tucked into beach bags and backpacks, sprinkled across picnic tables and dropped into the crooks of hammocks. Like their siblings the summer blockbuster and the song of the summer, they come: The season of summer reading has arrived.

headline: Good Fences Make Good Neighbors? Not at Opus 40.
text: SAUGERTIES, N.Y. — The 6.5-acre bluestone labyrinth rising out of a quarry here is one of the marvels of the Hudson Valley, an artistic tour de force by a self-taught sculptor who spent more than half his life creating it with thousands of rocks, infinite patience and no cement.

headline: In South Africa, Poachers Now Traffic in Tiny Succulent Plants
text: STEINKOPF, South Africa — On a moonless night in the desert in the far west of South Africa, Avrill Kaffer had just finished making a sale when vehicles with flashing lights emerged out of the darkness and an officer from the Stock Theft and Endangered Species Unit leapt from behind a nearby bush, ordering him to the ground.

headline: As Fears Grip Afghanistan, Hundreds of Thousands Flee
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Haji Sakhi decided to flee Afghanistan the night he saw two Taliban members drag a young woman from her home and lash her on the sidewalk. Terrified for his three daughters, he crammed his family into a car the next morning and barreled down winding dirt roads into Pakistan.

headline: For Tenants Nationwide, a Scramble to Pay Months of Rent or Face Eviction
text: For almost a year, a federal moratorium on evictions allowed tenants who suffered economic losses from the coronavirus pandemic to stay in their homes.

headline: Katie Ledecky now has the most individual Olympic golds of any female swimmer.
text: Katie Ledecky, the U.S. swimmer, has always tried to distance herself from the field, and the Tokyo Olympics have been no exception.

headline: India’s married archers: ‘We are a powerful couple.’
text: TOKYO — When love’s arrow struck, Deepika Kumari and Atanu Das were ready with their own quivers. Known as Dee-Das in India, the couple are one of two pairs of married archers at the Tokyo Olympics.

headline: After 670 Days, the Blue Jays Finally Returned to Canada
text: TORONTO — When the coronavirus sent the world into lockdown in the spring of 2020, the area surrounding Rogers Centre in the heart of downtown Toronto became something of a desolate wasteland. The familiar sounds of the walk-up crowd on game day and scalpers shouting at the top of their lungs were replaced by socially distanced outdoor yoga groups, residents taking their daily walks with their pets, and the occasional tennis enthusiast working on their forehead against the brick wall adjacent to the stadium entrance.

headline: New Zealand women’s rugby sevens grabs gold.
text: New Zealand’s women’s rugby sevens team captured the gold medal on Saturday, beating France, 26-12.

headline: ‘This Could Have Been a Zoom Meeting’: Companies Rethink Travel
text: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Belinda Bencic of Switzerland wins tennis singles gold.
text: TOKYO — Belinda Bencic of Switzerland won gold in the women’s singles tennis tournament on Saturday night, beating Marketa Vondrousova of the Czech Republic and positioning herself to be one of very few players to win singles and doubles gold in the same Olympics.

headline: Elaine Thompson-Herah of Jamaica wins the 100-meter dash.
text: TOKYO — Elaine Thompson-Herah of Jamaica on Saturday repeated as the Olympic champion in the women’s 100 meters, outsprinting a field that included Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a two-time former champion.

headline: Mourning Families Seek Solace From the ‘Grief Purgatory’ of Covid-19
text: The obituary had promised memorial services at a later date, so in May, Jessica Zimmerman-Selvidge sifted through photos of her father, trying to find the best ones for a celebration of his life.

headline: The Long Kiss Goodbye: Will Covid End the French Bise Forever?
text: Twice a year, Louise Al-Hakkak would sit on her front porch in Burgundy, waiting for her sister Flora and dreading the moment of “la bise.” In this Franco-Iraqi family, only Flora enjoyed France’s traditional two-kiss greeting on the cheeks. For Ms. Al-Hakkak and her father, “It was more a chore than anything else.”

headline: ‘The war has changed.’ In just days, the U.S. shifts tactics against the virus.
text: What a difference a week makes. In just a few days, state and local authorities have imposed mask mandates, companies have put off returning workers to their offices, and the federal government and the military have pressured their employees to get vaccinated.

headline: Are Your Neighbor’s Pesticides Bad for Your Children, Pets and Plants?
text: Q: I live in Westchester County, N.Y., and received a notice from my neighbors that they will be applying commercial pesticides to their lawn. I have small children, a dog and a large vegetable garden, and I’m concerned about the pesticides drifting onto my property and harming all of them. How concerned should I be, and what can I do to protect my family?

headline: The Rise of Mixed-Gender Relays at the Tokyo Olympics
text: TOKYO — After winning bronze in one of the new Olympic events at the Tokyo Games, Alejandra Valencia of Mexico recalled the moment when her partner nearly blew it.

headline: Already Distorting Jan. 6, G.O.P. Now Concocts Entire Counternarrative
text: In the hours and days after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, rattled Republican lawmakers knew exactly who was to blame: Donald J. Trump. Loyal allies began turning on him. Top Republicans vowed to make a full break from his divisive tactics and dishonesties. Some even discussed removing him from office.

headline: A Vulgar Anti-Biden Banner: Protected Free Speech?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Key Afghan City in Danger of Falling to the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An important city in Afghanistan’s south was in danger of falling to the Taliban on Saturday as their fighters pushed toward its center despite concerted American and Afghan airstrikes in recent days.

headline: Stranded Killer Whale Survives With Help of Good Samaritans
text: Boaters in Alaska came upon a peculiar sight on Thursday: A 20-foot-long killer whale was on the shore, stuck in a crevice of rocks.

headline: Tokyo Olympics on Saturday: Ups and Downs
text: Elaine Thompson-Herah extends her reign, Novak Djokovic loses and a different set of gymnasts bounce toward gold.

headline: Why Do Republicans Hate Cops?
text: WASHINGTON — It was, I must admit, a virtuoso performance by Sean Hannity.

headline: A Smarter Way to Make Decisions About Your Kids
text: When we become parents, we expect to be many things: someone who wakes in the middle of the night and who cleans up food from the floor; someone who comforts, who loves, who disciplines, who celebrates. What we perhaps did not expect is to take on the job of logistics manager. It creeps up on us as children age. The floor may get cleaner and the midnight wake-ups less frequent, but in their place is the stress of competing demands on our children’s time and ours. Which school to go to and how to get there? Is evening math tutoring necessary? What do we do about summer camp? How can three children with two parents be at three birthday parties on Saturday at 2 p.m.?

headline: ‘All Things Seemed Possible for Humanity’: Why We Watch the Olympics
text: My 4-year-old buried his head in my hip and let out a short, gaspy shriek. It could have been thrill. It could have been fear. Maybe both? We were watching a video of Simone Biles’s qualifying floor routine at the Tokyo Olympics — the first Games my son will experience.

headline: U.S. fencers wear pink masks to protest against teammate accused of sexual misconduct.
text: Alen Hadzic, an alternate on the U.S. Olympic fencing team who is accused of sexual misconduct, has been ostracized in Tokyo and prevented from staying in the Olympic Village.

headline: How Fast the Jamaican Sprinters Ran to Sweep the Women’s 100 Meters
text: The gold medalist, Elaine Thompson-Herah, averaged more than 21 miles per hour to finish the race in 10.61 seconds.

headline: Eviction Freeze Set to Lapse as Biden Housing Aid Effort Lags
text: A nationwide moratorium on residential evictions is set to expire on Saturday after a last-minute effort by the Biden administration to win an extension failed, putting hundreds of thousands of tenants at risk of losing shelter, while tens of billions in federal funding intended to pay their back rent sit untapped.

headline: Biden Promised to Restore the Iran Nuclear Deal. Now It Risks Derailment.
text: WASHINGTON — Days before a new hard-line president is set to be inaugurated in Iran, Biden administration officials have turned sharply pessimistic about their chances of quickly restoring the nuclear deal that President Donald J. Trump dismantled, fearing that the new government in Tehran is speeding ahead on nuclear research and production and preparing new demands for the United States.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: ACROSTIC — Full confession (and probably no surprise): This is my favorite flavor of acrostic, a little factoid-filled puzzle about the natural world. I think one a week would be delightful. Today’s passage is from a book called “Great Adaptations” by Kenneth Catania, about a variety of niche creatures who have evolved perfectly to their environments.

headline: Olympics’ First Openly Transgender Woman Stokes Debate on Fairness
text: TOKYO — When Laurel Hubbard, a 43-year-old weight lifter from New Zealand, makes her first attempt in the women’s heavyweight competition on Monday, she will become the first openly transgender female athlete to compete at the Olympics.

headline: Who Are the Unvaccinated in America? There’s No One Answer.
text: As coronavirus cases rise across the United States, the fight against the pandemic is focused on an estimated 93 million people who are eligible for shots but have chosen not to get them. These are the Americans who are most vulnerable to serious illness from the highly contagious Delta variant and most likely to carry the virus, spreading it further.

headline: Police in China Detain Canadian Pop Star on Suspicion of Rape
text: The police in Beijing said Saturday they had detained Kris Wu, a popular Canadian Chinese singer, on suspicion of rape amid a #MeToo controversy that has set off outrage in China.

headline: Frenchy Cannoli, Ardent Evangelist for Hashish, Dies at 64
text: Frenchy Cannoli, a renowned hashish evangelist who spent 18 years as a nomad learning to make the drug from the resin of the cannabis plant in rural parts of Asia, Africa and Mexico, died on July 18 in San Francisco. He was 64.

headline: How Strong Is Trump’s Grip on the G.O.P.?
text: This was a week of setbacks for Donald Trump in his attempt to maintain a firm hold on the Republican Party till 2024 and beyond.

headline: Russia’s New Form of Organized Crime Is Menacing the World
text: The screen goes blank.

headline: San Marino becomes the smallest country to win an Olympic medal.
text: TOKYO — San Marino waited 61 years for its first Olympic medal, which came on Thursday. Then it waited two days for its next one.

headline: ‘It’s Nowhere Near Over’: A Beach Town’s Gust of Freedom, Then a U-turn
text: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — By the Fourth of July, Provincetown’s tourist season had built to a prepandemic thrum. Restaurants were booked solid, and snaking lines formed outside the dance clubs. There were conga lines, drag brunches and a pervasive, joyous sense of relief.

headline: Delta Variant Drives Global Virus Surge, W.H.O. Warns
text: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the World Health Organization’s director general, said a worldwide rise in Covid-19 cases has disparately impacted poorer countries with lower vaccination rates, and that deaths in Africa have spiked 80 percent in four weeks.

headline: 233 staff members at 2 San Francisco hospitals have tested positive, most in breakthrough Delta infections.
text: At least 233 staff members at two major San Francisco hospitals, most of them fully vaccinated, tested positive for the coronavirus this month, and most, according to a hospital official, involved the highly contagious Delta variant.

headline: Protests against France’s vaccine pass surge for a third weekend, even as cases rise.
text: PARIS — Pascale Collino, 64, is far more afraid of the Covid-19 vaccines than of the disease itself. So when the French government decided to implement a new health pass policy barring those without proof of vaccination or a recent negative test from many indoor venues, she took to the streets in protest.

headline: Off Brand
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is an eccentric grid by a newish constructor, Matthew Stock, who works for a math-education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill. It’s his sixth puzzle for The Times and his second Sunday crossword, all from 2021 (you may remember “Karaoke Bars,” which spun through some pop favorites). I think today’s puzzle is a lot of fun and I found it to be one of the more difficult big grids that we’ve had recently.
